name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday 13 November 2014 to be resumed.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! Tomorrow we will receive His Holiness Pope Francis here. In this context, however, I would like to refer today to recent events in the Middle East. Last week, we witnessed a bitter attack on a synagogue in Jerusalem, a city that is a holy city for three religious communities in the world. The Middle East as a whole is deeply shaken by this attack. Five people died and countless were injured. It is certainly shocking for all of us when an attack is carried out on a church where people pray. In this case, it was a Jewish synagogue, but it also applies to every other place of worship where people want to pray for an attack. This is a new level of violence which I believe we all condemn in the strongest possible terms here in Parliament. The right of believers, regardless of religion, to pray in safety must not be endangered under any circumstances or at any time. That is why such attacks are an attack on peace. I appeal to everyone not to let the violence escalate. The endless cycle of violence and counter-violence must be ended. The senseless killing must stop. We have often called – and I repeat this on behalf of all of you – to call on those responsible to take the path of dialogue, to seek a peaceful solution. Today, of course, our sympathy and thoughts are of course with the victims and their families, to whom I offer our condolences on behalf of the European Parliament.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The final draft agenda for this part-session, as set out in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Thursday 20 November 2014 in accordance with Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed. The following amendments have been requested to this draft: Monday: the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has informed me that it intends to conclude the debate on the Commission's statement on the guidelines for impact assessment with a resolution. Mr Pieper has the floor to support this request.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr. President! We will be debating the impact assessment this evening, unfortunately without a resolution! This is about nothing more and nothing less than the impact assessment for small and medium-sized enterprises, which unfortunately no longer find themselves as a mandatory opinion in the Commission's new internal directives. Unfortunately, it is also a question of strengthening the discretionary margins of the Directors-General, so the impact assessment board has been weakened in its compulsory inclusion. These are things that are being decided these days. We do not want to accept that! That is why we want to implement a resolution on this week's debate, and I ask for your support for that.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr President, I would like to support that proposal. The text of the draft motion obviously still needs to be debated. There is a long way to go before reaching a conclusion, but I would hereby like to support it on behalf of the ALDE Group.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr. President, dear colleagues! The request was tabled just three days ago, and the shadow rapporteurs were also unaware. That is why the political groups have not yet had the opportunity to discuss it in depth, especially since we have not yet had a profound discussion on it in committee either. I believe that it is necessary to give the political groups time. It is also problematic because an international agreement is involved. If we want to continue to be taken seriously as interlocutors in international agreements, we should first of all take political decisions here without first presenting them to the European Court of Justice. Otherwise, we would have to refer many decisions before taking political decisions to the European Court of Justice. In addition, there is a great deal of legal uncertainty for European airlines, and the referral to the Court of Justice would delay the agreement by 12-36 months, which means that we may not be able to act appropriately on a very sensitive and very difficult issue, such as the fight against terrorism and serious crime, both as an international partner and as a European Parliament.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr. President! Why are we in favour of referral to the European Court of Justice? The majority of this European Parliament has never denied that passenger data can be an element in the fight against terrorism, and we have also given our assent to two agreements in the past. But we did so at a time when data retention was still valid within the EU. However, this directive has now been swept away by the European Court of Justice. This is now the first international agreement that we have to decide after this judgment. And, of course, the negotiators were unable to resolve this issue during the negotiations. However, I would like to point out that both the Council and the Commission could have clarified the extent to which this form of PNR agreement is compatible with European treaties and rights. They did not. I do not see any danger to the safety of citizens in Europe and Canada. Negotiations on the Canada Agreement have taken five years. During this time, the data has continued to flow, and it will continue to flow until there is a vote here in the House. I believe it is a good tradition that we ensure that everything we do for the security of our citizens does not violate fundamental rights. We want this clarification!

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Are there any further requests to speak on Tuesday? That is not the case. Wednesday: The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has requested that the vote on the motion for a resolution on the recognition of Palestinian statehood be postponed until the December part-session. Mr Preda has the floor to do so.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, on behalf of the PPE Group, we are calling for a postponement of the vote on this very delicate issue. I believe that we can keep the debate scheduled as it is and, seeing what is to come in the coming days and weeks in the parliaments of some member countries, vote on a joint text in December. I think it is not right for the European Parliament to be divided on this very delicate issue at this point.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Mr President, let me start by associating myself and our group with your words about the synagogue bombing. We are talking here about terrible death and bloodshed, and the tone in which we deal with it is really important. Secondly, I signal that my group wants a vote on recognition but wants to achieve consensus. We have said to other groups in this Parliament that we want to be as flexible as possible and to try to assemble a big majority. To my friend and colleague Mr Preda I would say that we have had some discussions on this. He has indicated that the PPE Group currently has a set position and is not prepared to go beyond it. We all understand the sensitivities. I believe compromises are available, but the position of the PPE tonight is that recognition can only be an outcome of talks. That, in fact, is the current situation. However, saying that this is a contribution towards the two-state solution and that peace will not be achieved without talks are, for example, possibilities. There is wording there from which we could negotiate – as the ALDE Group has said – recognising the debate and supporting the process. I believe a consensus is possible, but what concerns me – and we are delaying the vote as we speak – is that there is no indication at the moment of preparedness to look for that consensus. Therefore I would like us to go ahead with the negotiation on a text to see if we can achieve consensus. In conclusion, we see Sweden, Ireland, Spain, the UK, and soon France, voting for recognition. Does Parliament want to lose influence by coming in at the end of that process, or do we want to shape the debate?

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The EFDD Group has requested that the title of the Commission's statement on the situation of the steel industry be amended on Wednesday evening. Mr Tamburrano has the floor to speak on this.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in view of the importance of this issue in terms of social and employment aspects and given that this Union was initially born as a common market in coal and steel, the EFDD Group is calling for the item on Wednesday's agenda, 'Commission statement on the situation in the steel industry', to be changed to 'Steel sector in the European Union – protecting workers and industries' and for a resolution to be adopted in December to have a vote on the time necessary for its negotiation.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Furthermore, on Wednesday, the ECR Group requested that a Statement by the Commission on the irregularities in the Polish local elections and the resulting threat to democracy in Poland be included as the last item on the agenda on Wednesday, with a resolution. Who would like to speak in favour of this motion?

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I would like to make a request to include on the agenda this very point that you have been talking about, concerning gross – I repeat – gross irregularities in local elections in Poland and the related threat to democracy, which, in my opinion, has been the biggest since 1989. I request a statement from the European Commission on this subject, combined with the debate and resolution of the European Parliament. The elections in Poland were held in violation of the standards adopted by the European Union and the OSCE. During the electoral process, various events occurred indicating that it was not working properly. Public outrage led to the resignation of the entire composition of the State Electoral Commission. Announced only after six days, the official results deviate blatantly from the exit polls, with voters lodge numerous protests convinced that the elections were not conducted fairly. I believe that, when dealing with democratic processes in other countries, other than the European Union, in this House, we should also pay attention to standards that are at stake within the Union itself.

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: Mr President, I have a list here of the standards specified by the OECD – the conditions and the criteria for democratic elections. What happened in Poland is in blatant contrast with what I have here. I urge you to conduct a thought experiment. Imagine that, in your country, 20 – and sometimes 40 – per cent of votes are invalid. Imagine that, in the middle of the electoral process, the entire national electoral committee resigns. According to you, would that be compatible with democratic standards? If you think it is compatible with democratic standards, then vote against it. If you think there might be a problem here, please support us.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: I am against this proposal because it is an attempt to transfer to the European level the internal Political Debate of Poland and Poland, even if we speak other languages. The Polish-Polish debate, on the other hand, is our internal matter. Firstly, we have indeed had a failure of the IT system in Poland, secondly, I would like to point out that the electoral process in Poland is ongoing and thirdly, we have procedures that allow cases to be decided by independent courts. I request that the application which has been submitted be rejected. Thank you.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The order of business is therefore adopted.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the motion of censure against the Commission (2014/2197(INS)). First of all, I welcome the Commission, which, if I can see correctly, has taken full office, with the exception of Mr Oettinger, which is, of course, appropriate for the occasion. Mr Zanni has the floor for the first time in support of the arguments.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, over the past few days, reading the comments and statements of many of my fellow Members, I understand that everyone was very annoyed at this embarrassing situation concerning the newly elected President Juncker. I would therefore expect broad and unconditional support for this motion. But unfortunately I know that the situation will be different because this House has shown over the years that it is the temple of European hypocrisy. Let me give you a quick review from our GUE colleagues, who may not have noticed that we have just celebrated the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall and that perhaps we should also cooperate with those who consider it unpresentable, by virtue of their supposed moral superiority. Let us be quite clear that we do not accept lessons in democracy from anyone, because we have seen in recent months what is inside the concept of democracy, which for us is quite different and we are proud of it. I would like to say to my Colleagues on the Greens that the time has come to choose which side to stand on, either together with the grand coalition that governs Europe, or with us to change it. You have to decide, you can't keep having your foot in two shoes. A clear choice has been made by the Liberals, who, after the electoral ballast of the European elections, are now completely subject to the people and socialists. However, I would traditionally expect them to show pride, as Juncker has shown that he represents the antithesis to European ideals. But I would like to dwell for a moment on my Socialist colleagues and their President Pittella, who had said in recent days that he wanted explanations from Juncker or would have distrusted him. I ask you: are you satisfied with Juncker's non-answers? How can you believe that you will do what you have theoretically promised if, in practice, you have always behaved in the opposite way? Mr Pittella, you asked yourself whether Juncker was on the side of citizens or tax evaders. We all know clearly which side Juncker is on and it is certainly not that of the European citizens, who, as Prime Minister of the Grand Duchy, have taken billions of potential resources into the pockets of multinationals. I find it paradoxical that only we, what you call Eurosceptics, have remained to defend the interests of European citizens and the very dignity of Europe. You care about and only defend the interests of Juncker's friends, namely the large multinational capital and strong powers. Mr Juncker, you are the worst image of this Europe. At the head of the Eurogroup, she supported all European failed policies and at the same time as you starve Greece, she took billions from her European partners through agreements with the major international giants. If you had a shred of dignity, you'd have to leave. You have shown that you do not have the credibility to represent Europeans. With this motion we can give that strong signal of change that Europe needs. We are giving you all the opportunity to demonstrate that this Parliament, the only institution legitimised by the people, protects the interests of the citizens and not of the multinationals and banks, of the strong powers.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Mitglied der Kommission. - Herr President, meine sehr verehrten Damen und Herren! Zuerst mechte ich mich dafar entschuldigen, dass ich dieser Debatte nicht von Anfang an beiwohnen konnte. Das ist kein Zeichen der Unh-flichkeit, sondern ein Zeichen unbew-ltigter Verkehrsstrom zwischen Saverne und Strasburg. Ich bitte, das vielmals zu entschuldigen. Zu dem Misstrauensantrag der Kollegen selbst mechte ich sagen, dass ich mich in Bressel anlàsslich des letzten Plenums des Europeischen Parlaments uningeladen dem Parlament gestellt habe und die notwendigen Erkl-rungen abgeben habe. Nun kann man parlamentarische Debatten als die Vervielf-ltigung und Wiederholung derselben verstehen. Aber das, was ich am 13. November in Bressel zum Ausdruck gebracht habe, entspricht genau meiner Einsch-tzung der Lage. I have drawn the attention of all my colleagues here gathered to the fact that, from my point of view, the interaction between divergent national legal provisions leads to and leads to a situation that could lead, in extreme cases, to the under-taxation of European and third-party companies which will have to be avoided in the future and which in no way reflects what I will call the ethical and moral consensus which is of convenience. The problem is not only Luxembourg but more ecumenical, European, since advance tax rulings apply in twenty-two Countries of the European Union. That is why I have proposed a number of behavioural changes that we will have to adopt.  During the election campaign, during my inaugural speech on 15 July and during the Commission's inaugural address in October, I called for the establishment of a system that will be characterised by a common base in Europe with regard to corporate taxation. I added that I am in favour of the Financial Transaction Tax, which is no longer a matter for the Commission because we are engaged in a process of enhanced cooperation between the Member States concerned. I have called for the establishment of an automatic exchange system for early tax decisions between the Member States of the European Union. On behalf of Europe, I defended this issue at the G20 in Brisbane, Australia, and I was supported in my approach by the Heads of State or Government of France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Spain, Italy and the OECD Secretary-General. Despite this massive reinforcement, I must have noticed that the G20 was not able to mention in its conclusions the reference necessary for the automatic exchange of information, satisfied with a general sentence on transparency in advance tax decisions. All Europeans supported me, however, unless those who did not speak are suspected of fuelling different intentions. I would like to remind you that, when I was President of the European Union in 2005, President of the European Council and President of the ECOFIN Council, I proposed to my colleagues in the ECOFIN Council the establishment of a tax committee of the same rank as the Economic and Financial Committee so that we would be better able, at a high level, to follow the implementation of the conclusions of the Good Conduct Group and the code of conduct that we had adopted under my presidency. 1997. All of this has not been successful. I would like to invite the Council, the Italian Presidency, to propose again to the ECOFIN Council and to the European Council the establishment of a tax committee which will rank as high as the Economic and Financial Committee which, as a rule, prepares decisions and meetings of the ECOFIN Council. As for the motion of censure before us today, it has its place in the internal rules of this House. I would have preferred it to be introduced in due course, in November when I first spoke to this House after my decision. When I see the identity of the signatories of this motion of censure, I wonder about the profound meaning of it. I believe that I have to answer the questions that will be put to me every time this House asks, but I have the impression that the intention of the authors of this motion is not what they are echoing, since they should know that I am not a friend of the great capital. I repeat that the hilarity movement in the upper floors of European multinationals was great when I was accused of this friendship.  I want to add a few words. The motions of censure are addressed to the whole Commission and I have the impression that I am the only one being questioned. On 15 July, I said here that if the European Parliament ever withdrew its trust in a member of the Commission, he would be asked by the President of the Commission to resign. Leave the other commissioners alone. If You want me to leave, say it! And I'll leave!

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We had a detailed discussion on the matter in the last plenary session in Brussels. Jean-Claude Juncker has put forward proposals on how we can tackle the issues of tax justice in Europe. My group wants tax justice, we want to put an end to the fact that large corporations can withdraw from their tax burden and get out of it. But we also want us to make progress. That is why we need a Commission that puts proposals on the table and launches initiatives. That is what Jean-Claude Juncker has done, that is what the Commission intends to do, and it has our full support in doing so. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats will reject the motion on Thursday. Incidentally, I would like to point out that the whole Commission is present – a strong sign of unity and a sign that the gentlemen and ladies we elected four weeks ago want to work. They want to get to work, and we want to support them in that. (Applause) Farage, Le Pen and others who have signed may be delighted to see them again enjoying a few minutes of media attention. Incidentally, this only underlines the fact that all Members, including the right, have the same rights here in this House. When amendments are tabled, they are discussed and voted on. Unfortunately, however, our rights rarely receive attention because they never work constructively, but are always involved with the destructive. (Applause) Frankly, in the debate today, it goes through my mind that the issue we are talking about is actually the ideal world of Mrs Le Pen and Mr Farage. We are talking about tax issues. In tax matters, no EU Commission official has a formal decision to decide, since no Member of the European Parliament has anything to decide formally, there are not bad bureaucrats in Brussels who have to make a formal decision, but tax law is in the hands of the Member States, of sovereign, independent Member States, just as it is the ideal image of colleagues on the right. In practical terms, Why, in this ideal world in which Mr Farage and Mrs Le Pen live, is it really not possible to solve this tax problem? Ladies and gentlemen, the Europe that you have in mind is to blame for the fact that the corporations can take this out of themselves, the Farage Europe is to blame for the fact that these groups do not pay taxes today because the Member States are unable to solve the problem! (Applause) Because we are talking today about the initiators, about the EFDD Group, it is worth looking at this group. Mr Zanni of the Grillo people presented this initiative today. You are talking about': 'We are Europe!' I always ask myself: who is "we"?  I look at the EFDD Group, for example: the Grillo people are saying: 'We need more solidarity on immigration'. Farage walks around the UK and says: "I'm even throwing the Romanians out of Britain." There are Romanians and Poles in your group who say' that 'we need equal rights as the founding fathers of the EU in western Europe', and at the same time we are seeing Le Pen say' 'I do not want solidarity in this Europe, on this continent'. In your group, Mr Zanni, we have many colleagues who work with images of enemies, against foreigners, against refugees, against minorities, against Jews. There are many of us working with these images, and you are standing here and saying that they represent the new Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, you are not the new Europe, you are the old Europe! (Tumult) (Applause) Mr. President! I am looking forward to Thursday and to the vote because we are not voting on whether or not the Commission can continue to work. I want her to be able to work, and there will be a large majority for that. We will vote on Thursday on whether or not to give the right-wing populists and the right-wing radicals a success. I do not want this success for the right-wing radicals in this House! (Applause)

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I find it a little surreal that the explanation of a motion of censure, instead of explaining the reasons for censure, is a sum of insults to political groups and individual Members, who have only one flaw, that of having the head to reason independently, of wanting to decide what they want to do on a motion of censure in relation to the concrete things that are being proposed. I do not usually respond to insults, because there is an old maxim that says: 'He who spits in the air, in the head is caught', but there is one thing that deserves an answer and that is the accusation in this House. You see, there are hundreds of Colleagues here who often disagree with each other, but who have always defended and exalted the dignity and prestige of the European Parliament. The European Parliament is the only supranational institution directly elected by the citizens and we are here representing millions of citizens. (In response to the verbal assault carried out on a microphone by Mr Sn. Agea) You should be educated first, because the first rule is education. I did not reply to my colleague when he attacked my group and my person. And she's a distumata! With today's vote of no confidence, the European Parliament could, in spite of itself, go down in history: I do not think it has ever happened that an executive is distrusted 24 days after taking office. Let us see what happens if we send all the Commissioners home. The $300 billion investment plan that will be announced in two days' time would jump. This would erase Europe's last chance to create jobs and combat the crisis. Exhausting negotiations between the Member States to appoint the new Commission would begin again. Months would be spent forming a new college and, in the meantime, the European economy and society would collapse. In the absence of answers, unemployment would explode. Our continent would sink into deflation, maybe that's what you want? Perhaps that is the status quo, the quagmire, the lack of answers that you want? We're not there! Mr President, dear Commissioners, what you must fear today is the citizens' motion of no confidence. If we do nothing against the crisis, we will all be wiped out! And so I say to you: at work! At work, to launch the investment plan! At work, to combat tax avoidance and evasion!  The practices of those multinationals which evade and evade taxes with the complicity of too many governments are extremely serious. We asked you about this, Mr President, two weeks ago, and you assured us that everything will be done to harmonise our tax systems and you convinced us in terms of content. We didn't give you a guarantee. We have given you proof and confidence based on the substance of your proposals and we will monitor that.  We're not waking up now! We did not have to wait for a few newspaper headlines to denounce the dubious tax practices of multinationals and governments. Parliament has worked. I have mentioned the proposals contained in a European Parliament report adopted during the last parliamentary term: concrete proposals that we will take up again and entrust to the wise work of the European Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and European Affairs. This is the serious way to combat a scourge as big as that of tax avoidance and evasion. But this is also the serious way to move a Government, a Commission and a European President forward, so that they work in the interests of our fellow citizens.

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I will not be speaking about the personal virtues or vices of the authors of this motion because I do not know the authors of this motion or their intentions. I am not interested in that. What I will be speaking about is the Juncker problem. There is such a thing as the Juncker problem. President Juncker, let us admit that you did not make a good start. Moreover, I am not quite satisfied with what you said last time, and I am not utterly convinced by what you said today. If you will pardon the expression, I did not have the feeling that you have any pangs of conscience at all. It is a rare thing in politicians, but sometimes it is quite possible. But one thing must be clear enough. We really need full information about the special tax agreements and all the possible ramifications. When I said we need it, I meant ‘we’ meaning the European peoples – the peoples of Europe against whom these agreements were directed, including my own country, which lost several billions of euros as a result of the unethical ingenuity of the leaders of Luxembourg. That is not a minor issue. When I say ‘we’, I also mean the MEPs, the majority of whom voted for you not long ago. It is also good for you, President Juncker. You need it yourself because, whatever you do as President of the Commission, the shadow of this scandal will follow you with your name attached to it until the matter is settled once and for all. Who should do the investigating and the explaining? Of course, primarily the authorities of Luxembourg and independent international bodies, and forums such as the OECD. But I must say that I feel somewhat uneasy about the Commission with you, President Juncker, at its helm investigating the case. I do not know about you, but I personally feel deeply attached to the old Roman principle nemo iudex in causa sua: no one is to be a judge in his own case. I believe the old Roman principle is sacred, and we cannot violate it unless we want to make a laughing stock of ourselves. It is utterly unacceptable to seize this opportunity to go ahead with the plan for tax harmonisation – not now, if ever at all, not under this pretext, not in the state the EU is in now, and certainly not with the Commission under your leadership. (Applause)

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, personally I think that we should not waste too many words on this motion. Why? Because I think that everybody can feel, and even the spokesmen of the ECR can feel, that it is nothing more than a little game played by the two groups – the EFDD of Mr Farage and the group of Ms Le Pen (NI). I understand this game; it is a game that is normal in politics, I should say, based on what I call a perverted logic. The logic of this motion is perverted because what they want is that we should make a judgement on ‘Lux Leaks’ before the investigations by the Commission and by Parliament; and that is not serious at all. To come forward now with a motion at a time when we are asking the Commission to look into the matter and when we are actually about to set up a parliamentary committee - what is this nonsense, to start with a motion of censure before we have even started to investigate? For me, the only interesting thing about this motion is not its content; it is the fact that, finally, Mr Farage and Ms Le Pen are now finally outing their hidden relationship. That is the most important thing about this motion: their hidden relationship; the fact that they are actually following the same populist strategy, contrary to what Mr Farage said to his voters in Britain. Indeed it is proof of the fact that UKIP is hideous, racist, xenophobic and islamophobic. Those are not my words; they are the words of the founder of UKIP, Mr Alan Sked himself. So, in my opinion, your group – and I say that to Mr Zanni – is in fact not at all interested in clarifying or resolving international tax avoidance; and I find it very strange that Mr Zanni is pointing the finger at us. Put your own house in order, Mr Zanni, because one of the big specialists in all this is Mr Farage. It is he who has an off-shore tax team in the Isle of Man. So put your own house in order. I should in fact say the same thing to Ms Le Pen, because in a few minutes we shall have the fury of Ms Le Pen coming over this House again. In fact, she borrows money from dodgy Russian banks to finance her political actions. Nobody else does that. So I believe that in reality – and Mr Weber has already indicated that he has said really true things – she and you, Mr Farage, are against Europe, and it is not in this way that we shall have more European cooperation. My conclusion is very simple: let us get back to work and let us vote against this stupid motion. (Applause)

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: Mr President, do you think that disgraceful speech enhances the credibility of this Parliament, or not?

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work he has done. Our criticism of you remains, and we have already expressed this criticism during the first joint hearing, when you presented yourself in our group. We pointed out at the time how problematic it is – given the accusation that Luxembourg is a tax haven, that corporate taxes are being evaded there – to start here with the aim of closing precisely these tax loopholes and ensuring fair taxation within the European Union. When the documents became known – and it was only about the documents of companies that have teamed up with PricewaterhouseCoopers, So we were advised by those who were 340 companies, 340 companies for which there were 548 so-called rulings in Luxembourg – after that we immediately said: we must open a debate here in the European Parliament that makes it clear that change, the way forward, towards more solidarity, to financing that is actually used for solidarity-based European integration, and here also credibility in the European Union must be at the forefront. And we asked you how you feel about it. And I can only say on the part of my group that we were also disappointed by your speech ten days ago in Brussels! We were expecting clearer words. We expected you to understand that it is not just a criticism of you as a person, but that it is the criticism of a system that now bears your name. The Juncker system. That is the problem at stake here! It's not just about you! The point is – and you said this in a minor sentence – that 22 Countries of the European Union are now practising precisely this system in different terms and in terms of design. You asked Verhofstadt, you reminded him of his role. You have certainly not done so wrongly. But what is at stake if credibility is really to be achieved would be a very clear commitment to your responsibility. You have tried to explain that, as President of the Commission, you do not stand for Luxembourg. And that is not possible! That is absolutely not possible, we will not take that away from you! For this reason, we also made a motion at the time, a motion of censure. Unfortunately, we did not get the signatures for this, because we have made it clear from the outset that we do not want votes from the right-wing camp, the far-right nationalists. Because the Europe that these Members want is a different Europe. I will refer to the submission of the motion earlier. You have called for the European Union to be changed together with you. But they did not say where this change should go. I believe that this is the crucial point. That is the point that distinguished our request from what parts of you want. And anyone who goes to the motion with Mr Farage and Marine Le Pen cannot and should not be surprised that others refuse. It is up to you to say that we want to change, we want to go in one direction, to go towards a social union based on solidarity. But then you will also have to decide with whom you are in a group. Then you have to decide with whom you go on an application. We stick to it: we want this change. And here we are also disappointed by the Greens, we also say that we are disappointed with the Social Democrats that ten days ago they did not take the opportunity to discuss it with us and to make the debate here public about what other Europe we want to have on the tax issue. That would have been an opportunity! We now have the opportunity to get at least one committee of inquiry through together. That is more than a special committee. I appeal to all those who really want to see a change and finally put an end to the practice we have had to support this committee of inquiry!

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to make the following remarks to Mr Juncker. This is an ugly tax scandal that will not go away. The stain of deceit has seeped into you and, the longer you stay in that seat, the further the stain will seep up the chain behind you throughout the Commission. The stain is deep, because here in this Chamber today you have said that you are not a friend of big business; yet, whilst you were the leader of Luxembourg, you permitted 240 multinationals and corporations to enter into aggressive corporate tax avoidance. If that is what not being a friend is, I would love to see what being an enemy is. Some of these companies paid as little as one per cent, and yet you stood through the elections and said you wanted to stand in solidarity with the people of Europe. Yes, the people of Europe are in austerity, they have high rates of unemployment and there is poverty sweeping across Europe like a plague. Yet you ensured that the people of Luxembourg benefited from your largesse. You said that these were extreme circumstances, not just for your country; yet I do not see Germany or Britain or France or Italy having 240 companies with corporations earning one per cent. You talked of changes of behaviour, but the only behaviour that needs to change is yours. You ask others in this Chamber to attack us, simply because we are asking where the solidarity was when you put Greece through the troika, knowing millions of euros from dodgy tax deals with multinationals were flowing through Luxembourg’s coffers. Where is the solidarity when Italy has 55% unemployment and Luxembourg does not? Where is solidarity when you stood in this Chamber and said that these deals were done in the name of Europe? When I look at the people in this Chamber, you have to ask yourselves whether you are the moral guardians of the people who voted for you. Are you going to be seen as the Members who vote for your own and keep your own in place, or are you actually going to listen to the people and say that from time to time we must get rid of those who do not have the European ideal that you say that you believe in? (Applause from the right)

name: Marine LE PEN
text: Mr President, Mr Pittella, you are unpayable. You have forgotten, however, in your apocalyptic vision of the possible censorship of the Commission, the invasion of locusts and the rain of frogs. As for you, Mr Verhofstadt, you have not forgotten anything about all the insults and defamations that have engulfed your eructation, because I cannot find any other word in the rich French vocabulary, it must be said, to describe your intervention.  The reality is that, thanks to the leak of documents, we have further proof that Luxembourg is organising a very large-scale tax evasion in the European Union. More than three hundred multinationals have signed agreements with the country's administration to get big tax rebates. Once the rebate was obtained, the profits were repatriated to Luxembourg through various financial artifices. This little game has siphoned off the tax revenues of the countries of the European Union and, of course, those of France. Thus, French citizens will be pleased to learn that thanks to Mr Juncker, they must pay more taxes to compensate for the leakage of tax revenues organised by Luxembourg, which is not the only country concerned but plays a central role in the tax optimization schemes of multinationals. Techniques based on the artificial location of patents, transfer prices distorted between subsidiaries, combinations of subsidiaries between tax havens allow very wealthy multinationals to pay almost no tax in countries producing wealth. Merchant websites such as Amazon and ITunes have been able to locate artificial activities in Luxembourg and benefit from reduced VAT rates to sell their products in France. Worse, this VAT is collected in Luxembourg when it should return to the country of the consumer. It is a real tax toolkit that Luxembourg offers to multinationals, based - it is true - on the rules put in place by the European Union.  This has enabled Luxembourg to offer a very high standard of living to its inhabitants with highly paid financial and legal jobs. On the other hand, this has greatly impoverished other European Union countries. Mr Juncker, speaking of you in front of the French Senate, the former finance minister, Jean Arthuis, who is not exactly from my parish, said: "In the morning, he reminds us of our obligations to balance public finances and, in the afternoon, he makes our pockets thanks to the Luxembourg regime on taxation and banking secrecy". Mr Juncker, you were the Prime Minister of Luxembourg from 1995 to 2013. You are fully responsible for allowing these large-scale tax evasion techniques to be implemented. No supposed person can believe that you can fight sincerely and firmly to undo tomorrow what you have done. It would be as credible as appointing Al Capone as chairman of the Security and Ethics Committee.  That is why we are taking part in this motion of censure and asking all politicians who want to fight this scandalous escape to overthrow the Juncker Commission. It should be noted that you are not the only one responsible, you are just the best example of the monster that has become the European Union but we do not forget who made you King Mr Juncker: the EPP, the PES and the liberals as well as, in France, the UMP and the PS, carry with you the opprobrium of the symbol you have become, that of a Europe of scheming , greed, injustice and cynicism that abandons the small in favour of the bigger ones.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, there is a great temptation to answer only to Mrs Le Pen, who covers me with tenderness every time she speaks in this Chamber. Irrespective of that, however, I would like to respond to some elements of the debate that have been put forward. Frau Zimmer, Sie reden von einem "System Juncker." Mit welchem Recht tun Sie das? Sie haben - wie viele andere Kollegen auch - darauf hingewiesen, dass das System, das Sie mit meinem Namen belegen, eigentlich das Gesamtresultat widerspr-chlicher innerstaatlicher steuerlicher Gesetzgebungen in ganz Europa ist. Also belegen Sie ein System, an dessen Ursprung ich nicht stehe, das ich nicht herbeigef-hrt habe, das ich nicht systematisiert habe, sondern das sich aus den unterschiedlichen steuerlichen Bestimmungen in unseren Mitgliedstaaten ergibt, nicht mit meinem Namen! Before you, I have said repeatedly that the Commission I have the honour of chairing will fight tax evasion and tax evasion. I said before you less than a fortnight ago what instruments we are going to use to ensure that such non-taxation phenomena can no longer occur because they do not meet the normal ethical and moral requirements. I have asked my colleague, Mr Moscovici, to draw up a directive which will ensure that there is now an automatic exchange of information on early tax decisions between us between the 28 Member States. I understand that all the groups support this approach, I have not heard a single voice saying that it should not be conducted. I therefore want to believe that, in your countries, in your parties, in your national parliaments, you will deploy treasures of influence so that the twenty-eight Member States will accompany the Commission on this path. I'm counting on you. It is not enough to make pathetic appeals to me, it is a question of ensuring that, in each country, the consensus is established around the idea that, in terms of early tax decision, an automatic exchange of information will be needed.  When I proposed in Brisbane, Australia, that this rule become a global rule, I noted that the enthusiasm of others was very limited. So we will all have to make sure that the consensus is reached around this idea. I understand that all the parliamentary groups, all the members of this House will support me, when I ask the Italian Presidency and those who will follow, to set up, at the level of the Council of Ministers and the Member States, a tax group that will ensure the scrupulous application of the requirements arising from the code of conduct against unfair tax competition. , which we set up in 1997. In 2005, this idea was rejected when I proposed it. Today, I note that all Members of the European Parliament agree that a tax committee will have to be set up, on an equal footing with the Economic and Financial Committee, which will ensure the proper application of the rules and which will accompany, in formulating proposals, the Council of Ministers of Economy and Finance when it comes to setting up this system. I am advocating for tax harmonization, which is not a plea against tax competition. Tax competition is healthy, unhealthy when it is unfairly conducted. The Commission I have the honour of chairing will fight with all its might against unfair tax competition. Don't question my word. I am speaking before a European Parliament. I am speaking to the European Parliament when I commit myself, on behalf of the Commission, to realising what is one of the basic elements of the programme that I have set out to you and on which I have been elected. I intend to stick to that, and I expect that all commissioners will stick to it, which they will do. And I expect that all those who have invested in the Commission, which I chair, will ensure that the Commission's programme is implemented, both its principles and the details. That is my commitment. I have a contract with Parliament. I was elected on a $300 billion investment program, which I will have the honour of presenting to you on Wednesday morning. I was elected on basic principles relating to the functioning of European democracy. I was elected on a draft tax rules that I intend to implement and I would like everyone who knows the subject - and there are many of them because they have been prime ministers, finance ministers, national MPs - to support me in this process. I say it very solemnly...

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Davor Ivo Stier, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on the EU and the global development framework after 2015 (2014/2143(INI)) (A8-0037/2014).

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Rapporteur. - Mr. President, in affirming its role in international relations as a force for good, as a force for promoting and respecting the dignity of every human person, the European Union has achieved the most in the field of development policy.  The European Union is indeed a global leader here, not only because it is the largest donor, but also because as a community based on democratic values it is absolutely convinced of the universality of every man's right to peace and freedom, to a dignified life, to the right of every society to development, to sustainable economic, social and environmental development. This is why it is important that in preparing a new Global Development Framework after 2015, in the international negotiations to be conducted next year, the European Union takes a strong and unified position, to speak with one voice.  With a Resolution of the European Parliament, we therefore send a clear message to the Council that in December we want Member States to put aside what separates them and put emphasis on what brings us Europeans together in the fight against poverty in the world, in the fight against inequalities, in promoting sustainable development. In December, we want the Council to adopt a common position for the European Union to strongly and effectively enter into negotiations for a new Global Development Framework that will replace the old Millennium Goals of 2000 and adopt a new set of post-2015 targets.  This new Global Development Framework must be transformative, it must touch not only on the symptoms but also on the causes of poverty and modern sleuths that oppress human dignity and prevent sustainable development.  In doing so, we do not want to diminish the importance that the Millennium Goals have had so far and all their positive effects, especially in middle-income countries. But we also need to note that this progress, especially when it comes to economic growth, has not been felt equally by everyone. Despite the achievements of the Millennium Goals so far, there is still a "hunger scandal" in the world, as Pope Francis himself has pointed out, which we will receive in the European Parliament tomorrow. And indeed, it is a scandal, because there is food in the world for everyone, but there is no justice for all. That is why in this resolution we stressed that the new Global Development Framework must be imbued with a single approach that will be based on promoting the rule of law and respecting human rights.  In this regard, we welcome the work of the United Nations Open Working Group, which has proposed a new set of objectives, among which there are innovative objectives that coincide precisely with this view. In the upcoming negotiations, we want to preserve this, in particular goal number 16, and we would like to remain ambitious and also stress the need to promote "good rule", "good governance", because we think it is necessary if we really want a transformative framework that will be effective in eradicating poverty, fighting inequalities and promoting development. We know that it will not be easy to insist on this principle of "good rule" in international negotiations, but we must do so, otherwise corruption will eat up funds that are intended for development, will allude or even surpass development efforts, and the gap between the extremely poor and the extremely rich will continue to widen. For the success of the transformative Global Development Framework, we also need a renewed Global Partnership for Development in which new growing economies must take greater responsibility, but also the private sector, of course with clear guidelines and control mechanisms. We also need to involve civil society, local authorities and national parliaments more. The resolution also highlights the central role of women in development policy. Unlike the Millennium Goals, which were intended only for developing countries, we want the new Global Framework to set targets for all countries in the world, including the European Union and its Member States. In this resolution, we emphasise such a principle of universality and therefore the need for the European Union to bring all its foreign and internal policies in line with the new objectives. Colleagues, we live in a globalized world where both our security and prosperity in Europe are more connected than ever to the fate of those poorest who are on the margins of the international order. Let's just look at the ebola epidemic situation. Didn't we in Europe feel the consequences of the absence of a coherent health system in West Africa that could not stop the virus from spreading massively in time.  Europe cannot be safe if it is surrounded by the hungry and extremely poor. Extreme opportunities for poverty, bastards and hopelessness are fertile ground for the spread of radical forces. Effective development policy is therefore the best response against any radicalism, and this of course also applies to opportunities within the European Union.  Finally, Mr. President, I want to say that in preparing this resolution we have worked together, all political groups, and therefore I especially want to thank all shadow rapporteurs for their constructive approach. We now expect this same approach from the Council so that the European Union speaks with one voice and remains a force for Well, strength for development.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I welcome this timely report and thank Mr Stier as rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs and the Committee on Development for their efforts in putting together a clear set of messages for the post-2015 agenda. This is indeed a very valuable contribution that will help shape the EU’s position on this important issue. The global debate on the sustainable development goals represents a profound shift in the way the world thinks and acts in international development. I warmly welcome Parliament’s active engagement in this important political discussion, which resonates widely with the public. Today 1.2 billion people still live in extreme poverty. The geography and demographics of poverty are changing. For instance, new actors, emerging economies and private foundations are coming forward, some of them donors in their own right. New conflicts and demands for better governance are reshaping parts of the world. Our planet’s natural resources are in decline and the impacts of climate change and biodiversity loss are becoming close to irreversible. This is why, when addressing Parliament as Commissioner-designate about two months ago, I made it absolutely clear that an ambitious post-2015 development framework is my top priority. The Millennium Development Goals have been enormously helpful in guiding our development efforts since 2000, but we need a new agenda to meet the new challenges before us today: an agenda that includes all three dimensions of sustainable development – social, economic and environmental – in an integrated and balanced manner; an agenda that addresses inequalities and takes a human rights-based approach. The universality principle is a profoundly important feature of this new framework. Universality means that the new framework will apply to all countries of the world, while taking into account national contexts, capacities and levels of development. It also means that the new goals will have far-reaching implications for the EU institutions and for Member States’ domestic policies. I invite Parliament to continue proactively to engage in this important agenda, not only from the development perspective but across all the relevant policy areas. I believe this report is a helpful contribution to a stronger EU position, and I hope it will also help engage our citizens, mobilise support for sustainable development and demonstrate the benefits of working together in shaping our common future. I look forward to our debate today and to continuing our dialogue in the months ahead.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. - (C) As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Gender Equality, I cannot strongly emphasise the importance of a clear and strong gender perspective in the post-2015 global development framework. Women's rights need to be given much greater priority than they are today. We call for a specific gender equality objective and we also call for gender mainstreaming to be integrated into all parts of the global development framework. This is included in the report we are debating and will vote on tomorrow, and that is why it is supported. I want to highlight some of the bets that need to be made. A crackdown on gender-based violence is needed, greater investment in girls' schooling and education is needed, and efforts are needed to strengthen women's economic independence and livelihoods. And not least, it takes a focus on sexual and reproductive health and rights, including contraception, including abortion, something some in this house want to deny women. That is unacceptable. It is 2014 and funding for family planning must increase, not as it is today.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent I support this high-quality report by Mr Stier, because it presents in a comprehensive way the possibilities for dealing with the issue of the well-being of people from developing countries. I agree that it is the fight against poverty that should remain a priority on the post-2015 development agenda. As a member of the Committee on Culture and Education, I cannot help but draw attention to the importance of access to quality education, as this adequate knowledge is very often a determining factor for the development of the individual, which gives hope for a way out of poverty. Nor can the issues of human rights and the rule of law and social justice be overlooked, as they are directly linked, since only in the case of equal access to employment, education or other privileges for all, can the sustainable development of a particular region be possible.  It is therefore important to maintain the 16th point on sustainable development proposed by the UN, which calls for the promotion of a peaceful, integrated society, the rule of law and the effective operation of state institutions. I also agree with the statement that local authorities cannot be deprived of their competences, because they are the authorities who know the needs of their citizens best. I call on the Council and the Member States to adopt a unified and coherent EU position in the December Council conclusions. Member States must be firm on the main provisions, but flexible on the details that may divide them, without jeopardising the common Union position that is necessary to maintain the Union's leadership in the negotiation process. Thank you. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party(S&D), we can only be pleased today to be able to present this report to the House. With the rapporteur, Mr Stier, and the other shadows and all my fellow Members who have contributed, we have done an enormous amount of work in a very short space of time, in a collaborative spirit and with an awareness of the importance of this report, which will constitute this Parliament's position on the definition of the Sustainable Development Goals to be negotiated at the United Nations next year. It is an ambitious and balanced report which met with a very large majority in committee. It is essential that we find an equally strong majority in this House, so that we can present a united position of Parliament and influence the council conclusions of mid-December. As an S&D group, we have placed great emphasis on human rights, which must be at the heart of the new framework, insisting on the principle of non-discrimination and attention to the most vulnerable, as well as minorities, the LGBT community and people with disabilities. We wanted to emphasize the importance of a new global partnership, emphasizing the universality of the new objectives, the real novelty and the real challenge for the coming years. No longer an agenda for developing countries, but shared objectives that apply to all states, including those of the Union.  We have put at the centre the leading role that the European Union will have to play in future negotiations and that it will be able to play all the more strongly the more it is able to speak with one voice, unity and stronger. We wanted the fight against all inequalities to become a top priority on the new agenda at the same level as eradicating poverty and sustainable development. Europe can and must take responsibility for promoting a close fight against inequalities on a global scale, and it must also set an example. Inequalities that have increased incredibly both within states and between states, and to which many of the great challenges we face on a daily basis, such as migratory flows, are linked. It is also important to insist on inequalities because one of the critical issues of previous Millennium Goals is that, although progress has been made, their distribution has been unequal between different social groups.  That is why in the report we clearly defend the Open Working Group's proposal to have a separate objective on reducing inequalities. We wanted to take the work of the Open Working Group as its basis and we believe that the objectives should not be reduced but that, if they are to be reorganised, it must under no circumstances be at the expense of the most ambitious and innovative objectives, including the one on the equality agenda.  As a member of the FEMM Committee, I am delighted that the committee's opinion has been taken very seriously and, as previous speakers have said, the report strongly shows the central role of women in development policies and full respect for their rights, including sexual and reproductive rights.  There are many other innovative and courageous aspects: the fight against poverty, for example, which we are calling for to be measured not only on the basis of income but by taking broader measures of progress and well-being, as well as the desirable raising of the poverty line to two dollars a day; climate change and the need to move decisively and courageously towards finally sustainable production and consumption models; universal access to quality health and education for all; the need to combat corruption, tax evasion and avoidance, which deprive countries of essential resources, including with regard to innovative forms of financing such as the financial transaction tax; and finally the important role played by civil society, organisations, local authorities and national parliaments in the new framework, which will be all the stronger the more shared and built with more hands.  In this sense, we have insisted on the need for all the actors involved, including the private sector, to always be guided by achieving the objectives of development cooperation, respect for human rights, the protection of workers and the environment and the principles of transparency and accountability.  It is a strong and ambitious report, which we hope will find the broadest support from our colleagues - not least because next year will be European Year of Development - with the knowledge that we are also going to vote on the future of our cooperation policy and in the hope that the Union, also with the contribution of the High Representative, Commissioner Mimica and the President of the European Council, will be able to take part in the debate. , may make you feel strong its voice in the community of states, in support of a world not only free from poverty, hunger and disease but also fairer, more equal and more attentive to sustainable development and to the rights of all and all, because I believe that this is our responsibility towards the new generations. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – I believe that countries should act quickly when we have disasters or crises such as the Ebola virus, where nations acted shamefully slowly and without comprehending the reality of the situation, but I do not want to see the wrong kind of aid – aid which engenders dependence; aid to countries with nuclear or space programmes; aid which enforces a western world-view on other cultures; or aid for members of the G20. Do you accept that there are potential dangers with poor implementation, as so often happens at EU level?

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: answer to a "blue card" question. There is an important part of the report that is specifically devoted to Disaster Risk Reduction , which is why we have also insisted on the issues of accountability and transparency of all funds and aid. It is certainly a very important subject and it is covered in the report.

name: Marek Józef GRÓBARCZYK
text: The European Union declares its objectives of ensuring technologically advanced economic development, building a knowledge-based society and combating social exclusion and poverty. These objectives within the framework of the Millennium Agenda should be achieved globally and locally. The latter local aspect requires particular attention, as economic growth planning and legislative and management action must not ignore social considerations. The european bureaucracy policy so far has deindustrialised the south and east of the European Union, enlarged the area of social inequality and poverty, and, above all, has resulted in an unprecedented scale of economic emigration. As a result of this policy, and with the participation of the government from my country, 2.5 million people have emigrated to seek work. The implementation of EU policies has resulted in the job losses of thousands. This has primarily affected the maritime economy, which should be a pillar of knowledge and innovation, job creation and growth opportunities for the younger generation. It is therefore necessary to rebuild industry and, above all, the maritime economy, which is a prerequisite for returning to sustainable development and combating poverty and social exclusion.  I therefore call on the Commission to develop a comprehensive programme for the recovery of the economy, including the maritime sector, so that all regions, including Western Pomerania, most affected by the current harmful policy, have a chance of development. Thank you. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – I can agree with your intervention on the need for reindustrialisation. My question is whether you do not believe that deindustrialisation is largely the responsibility of local governments, and not of the European Parliament. How do you see Parliament and the Commission's involvement in reindustrialisation in individual countries?

name: Marek Józef GRÓBARCZYK
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Honourable Member, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. In recent years, many jobs have been created as a result of the European Union's action. Ask the countries of southern Europe or Eastern Europe who was the reason for this policy. On several occasions, these actions have led to huge, unprecedented emigration. Among other things, it is the European Union and this policy of bureaucracy that has contributed to such a disastrous policy.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the ALDE Group welcomes the Stier report in the sense that all the things we consider important are involved. On the other hand, the report is too broad and too detailed. It became an even worse 'Christmas tree' than the report of the Open Working Group, which worked at the UN, which contains 17 development policy objectives. On behalf of my group, I said that the new Sustainable Development Goals would be clustered according to the five main objectives of development policy, which are - poverty eradication and the fight against inequality - economic sustainability - environmental sustainability - social sustainability and - global partnership. This proposal was taken into account in the final compromise. I hope that the Council and the Commission will take this idea forward. In any case, the new goals form a Christmas tree, but it must have a trunk and branches on which decorations can be hung. In this way, development policy will bring errence and effectiveness. The report, which has been drawn up on the basis of almost 500 proposed amendments, is not balanced. Some objectives have gained greater weight than others. When the Committee on the Environment did not deliver its own opinion, the weight of environmental issues is too weak. The amendments tabled by the ALDE Group partially eliminated this deficiency. The report emphasises the need for coherence in development policy, universality of development policy. The objectives of development policy must be formulated in such a way that they can and must be achieved equally, both in developing and developed countries. In Parliament, all committees will have to look into the new objectives set at the UN next autumn and ensure that they are realised, including in the Union and its Member States.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the Millennium Development Goals expire in 2015. This is a historic opportunity to set new, even more ambitious goals to end poverty, inequality and environmental destruction. After it has been enriched by the work of Lola Sánchez and also Members of other groups, Mr Stier's report goes in this line and includes some essential elements. We can mention, among others, the prioritization of tax justice, the recognition of access to health as a human right or the presence of a cross-cutting approach to gender. But possibly the most important element—and one that underlies everything else—is the express mention of the fight against rampant and savage economic inequality. The 85 richest people in the world own the same wealth as half of the poorest people. This is not only immoral; is that it is also a drag on the economy. Combating inequality must be a key element in the post-2015 framework. If we don't end inequality, we won't end poverty. I hope that the European Council will listen to the voice of this Parliament and I hope that we will continue to work generously to make the Post-2015 Agenda a really ambitious and effective thing.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the We have before us a very important report which is intended to further develop the Millennium Goals. This is desperately needed! You can really take that very literally. Because billions of people live in poverty and hardship. More than 800 million people are starving every day. This is a very great responsibility and it is a very great challenge. In this report, we are constantly guided by human rights. Unlike the ALDE, I am very pleased that we are also consistently guided by the objectives of the UN's open working group. I am very grateful to Mr Stier for taking a holistic approach in this report to combat poverty, for his efforts to combat inequality at all levels and for the protection of women's and children's rights to be characterised. Women in particular play a special role in building stable economies on the ground. However, we must also ensure that this broad approach is maintained in the vote. I am a little concerned about the binding rules for our private sector, which are laid down in paragraphs 22 and 68. Because without binding rules in the private sector, which include a high social standard and also a high standard of environmental protection and which involve local people, we will not have a driving force of the private sector for sustainable and inclusive growth. This report here in the European Parliament alone will not satisfy any child in this world. We must put this report into action! We must continuously monitor development cooperation, equip it with money and concepts and always involve the local population. If we pursue our other policies coherently, we will be able to combat poverty in a sustainable way.

name: Nathan GILL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the EU claims to be a development actor concerned about the world’s poor. As we approach the Millennium Development Goal deadlines, perhaps we should examine what the EU has done for – or should I say to – the world’s poor. Perhaps we could talk about the EU pesticides directive, which prevents African countries using effective anti-malaria sprays. As a result, 90% of the world’s malaria deaths occur in Africa, the majority of them being children under the age of three. Or perhaps we could talk about the EU fishing boats plundering the fish stocks off the Horn of Africa. This has destroyed the livelihoods of peaceful fishermen, who resorted to piracy against container ships in order to stay alive. Or perhaps we could talk about the EU’s vindictive behaviour in trade talks, where the world’s poor are banned from exporting their most successful produce to European markets, stopping them from trading their way out of poverty and debt. As you can see, the EU is an actor in international development, but a spiteful and an inadequate one. The EU has so starved an impoverished Africa that it is perhaps no surprise that so many migrants risk their lives to escape it, but thankfully countries like India are coming to the rescue. India has invested money in high-yield crops in West Africa. This is infinitely more useful than the feel-good dance troupes the EU funded in the same region. The EU should stop impoverishing the world’s poor and let them have a chance to live. There are positive development actors in the world. The EU just is not one of them. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – Mr Gill, you have explained what you stand against and what foreign aid should be used for. What is your positive vision for foreign aid?

name: Nathan GILL
text: blue-card answer. – I think there is a real danger that we are entering into a period of aid fatigue. In my country we are already spending GBP 21 million each and every day on foreign aid, and this is on top of the money we are contributing to the EU budget which goes towards development aid. No one would object to disaster or emergency aid, but I am afraid that much development aid is objectionable. Instead of the many priorities that we see in this report, maybe we should have one priority, which should be to eradicate malaria – the world’s biggest killer.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, I would first of all like to congratulate my colleague, Davor Stier, on the preparation of this report and on his commitment to finding the widest possible compromise. It was not easy to find such a compromise, with 466 amendments tabled in the Committee on Development, a record number which, on the other hand, showed interest in this subject. I would like to return to some ideas that I supported by the amendments tabled in the Commission and which are contained in the text under discussion. I think we all want the Council to adopt a strong negotiating position in December. The Union must adopt an ambitious and effective common position on the principles and objectives that will be part of the new global framework for post-2015 development. If we are to have an impact on poverty reduction, we need a single, comprehensive and integrated framework with clear benchmarks that incorporates the main issues of development and sustainability. As Parliament's permanent rapporteur on the coherence of development policies, I would like to welcome the reference to this concept in the Stier report. The new global framework for development must indeed pay particular attention to the links between development and crucial areas such as trade, finance, energy, agriculture and the environment. At Union level, policy coherence for development is a well-established concept, but I believe that we need to take it to the next level and promote its global rooting.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, with the conclusion of the Millennium Development Goals at the end of 2015, world leaders have committed themselves: they have called for a plan, an implementation programme to tackle the inequalities that are too often important in this world. Of course, not all of the Millennium Goals have been achieved. It is already 2014 and many of them have not been reached. However, progress has been made, which means that we must continue our efforts. The post-2015 programming will address many themes, and I will focus only on the issue of equality between men and women.  In the past, four of the eight objectives were covered by this issue, which means that we must continue to pay attention to it. In particular, the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality called for three main objectives to be taken up: the first is access to education for girls, not only access to primary education but also access to secondary education; the second is access to health and universal access to sexual and reproductive rights; the third is the fight against all forms of violence: violence such as genital mutilation and rape as a weapon of war, but also the violence that European women suffer on a daily basis, even today Sustainable development for our planet will not take place in a world where half of humanity still suffers from gross inequalities.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Mr President, first of all, congratulations to rapporteur Stier, who managed to adopt a report and do so in committee in no time: it was a formidable and well-balanced job.  My second reflection is on unsatisfactory results: the implementation of the Millennium Development Goals as well as decided in 2000. The reasons for these lack of results must be questioned. There are many of them, including the inability of the international community to comply with the objectives it set itself in the 1970s. The disbursement of public aid to the tune of 0.7% of gross domestic product is poor, and this is also due in many European Union states.  The second reason is the mismatch between the production of wealth on the one hand and the capacity for redistribution on the other. One example is emerging countries that produce both rich and even more poor. We need to learn from this situation by empowering everyone in order to achieve a more effective approach. Let us start by introducing social security in all developing countries: it would be a powerful means of redistributing wealth and, at the same time, a trigger for progress in health promotion. We see how important this is to countries that are suffering from the Ebola epidemic, in particular

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Mr President, the draft decision we are discussing sets targets for global development after 2015, such as eradicating poverty, combating inequalities and respecting human rights, for which there should be broad agreement. I must point out, however, that the attitude of the dominant political forces on all this, both in the European Parliament and in the governments of the Member States, carries a great deal of hypocrisy, since opposing policies are being pursued within the Union. In the heavily indebted Member States in particular, notorious structural reforms translate into the violent impoverishment of most of society, for the benefit of domestic and, above all, international capital, as well as a systematic violation of social rights. I therefore believe that, instead of the European Union issuing grandiose declarations on the future of other continents, it would do well to see itself in the mirror and change course before it is too late.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we very much welcome the report we are debating today and believe that a great deal of work has been done. However, we believe that the issue of environmental sustainability and its consequences for human development should be central to the post-2015 development framework. The fight against climate change is a prerequisite for overcoming poverty and ensuring food security and sustainable development.  Climate change is not only an environmental problem but has many effects on a country's health, development and economy.
