For many developing countries that are unable to manage risks, reducing climate change means mitigating the risk of natural disasters that have a direct impact on the life and level of poverty in those areas. We call on the European Union, in establishing its negotiating strategy for the post-2015 development goals, to place the fight against climate change and actions to address it as one of its priorities.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: Mr President, the framework is important, necessary and useful, but it is also costly and does not provide any answers to very serious questions. Several issues, which are at the root of poverty and all human disorders, cannot be separated without mentioning the causes of it today.  First, the foreign policy of our states, too often under the influence of the United States of America, provokes or maintains conflicts that contribute to the development of misery with serious consequences, as we know them in Iraq, Syria, Libya, Central African Republic or Mali. Today's radical Islamists are often the game creatures of our democracies of yesterday who were used for political purposes and turned against us. Corruption? Not a word about corruption in this report! Corruption, however, is an important factor in the maintenance of conflicts and the plundering of resources in some countries through multinationals and transnational mafia networks. So what are the ways to control and spend the money? To whom is this money distributed?  Finally, there is no paragraph on the management of immigration when the issue of migration is linked to our development effort, in order to loosen the noose on Europe.  We therefore praise the good intentions of this report, but deplore these significant absences, which will continue to deal with the consequences without dachie on the real causes.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: If we want to talk about the Millennium Development Goals, we need to decide whether we consider them to be a serious plan or an advertising tool. If we take them literally, it means they ended in partial failure. Extreme poverty and hunger have still not been eradicated. We didn't beat HIV, malaria or tuberculosis. A sustainable environment has not been achieved. Child mortality has only been halved, not by two-thirds. It has not been possible to provide basic education for all children.  But I think such a view would make it impossible for us to see what is relevant. A huge shift for the better has been achieved in all objectives. The Millennium Goals must therefore be seen more as a call for concrete action. This is the most successful global development project. And if anything works, it needs to continue. However, abortion has never ensured any woman's health. The right to abortion, which is included among the so-called reproductive rights, is not a solution to child mortality or maternal health, as the text tabled to us in some paragraphs seeks to tell us. Women in developing countries need hospitals with doctors who follow the Hippocratic oath, not abortion clinics. We can ask Dr. Mukwege about this tomorrow. I support efforts to continue successful development projects that deliver results.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: It is essential that the debate on the post-2015 Development Agenda leads to clear priorities for sustainable development. And the report we are discussing here today, with all the contributions it has made, makes a relevant contribution to this debate and assumes what should be our ambition: to put the European Union, which is already the largest donor of development aid, in the leadership of this process, in defence of an ambitious, sustainable universal agenda and an agenda that saves no effort in combating poverty and inequalities. This implies an awareness of the seriousness of the problems and the importance of the challenges, but it also involves learning from the experience of cooperation policies, their remarkable progress and their deceiting failures. And experience teaches that we will not achieve development goals if adequate funding is not ensured and if the overwhelming majority of countries continue to fail in their commitments. As the European Parliament's rapporteur on development finance, I believe that the future agenda is only feasible if it is accompanied by an equally ambitious and innovative approach. The crisis cannot continue to serve as an excuse, but it is also true that the context of budgetary constraints calls for increased rigour in the control of innovative financial aid and financing instruments and greater involvement of the private sector. We have a lot of work ahead of us here in the European Parliament, listening to all partners and civil society before Isis Ababa and New York. The report I will present here will be a complement to the debate we are having here today and I am counting on everyone's contribution to an exercise in that policy coherence that is so lacking in the Development Agenda.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr. President! First of all, on a point of order. I think it is rather unnecessary – and I think the Rules of Procedure also consider it rather unnecessary – for questions to be asked within a group, especially before hand, by the EFDD or even by the PPE. I think they have enough time to ask each other these questions in their own group meetings. But now to the report, ladies and gentlemen. It reads very nicely, these are all noble goals that we read here: justice, equality, fairness. I can fully sign up for what is in it, ladies and gentlemen. However, it is also time to translate these words into action. Again, I doubt this, given the practice in this House. I was particularly alarmed by the figures and data cited in this report on the oppression of women. This is about mass rape, it is about genital mutilation, it is about ritual murders. These are all things that must no longer exist in the 21st century – certainly not in Europe! It must be clear to you and to us that these are also things that we ourselves have imported with mass immigration. I wonder why the Committee on Women's Rights and Equal Opportunities is discussing important things such as the Internal I rather than the really important things, such as this abuse of women and equality?

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Mr. President, since the European Union is the largest donor of development aid, then it must also lead the way in the negotiations ahead. We see here one innovation, Member States must act together, uniquely, coherently and it is important that this programme should apply to all countries of the world and therefore it is universally applicable.  I want to take this opportunity to thank Mr. Davor Stier, who authored this report, who really made the maximum effort in a short time and who showed along with his co-rapporteurs or shadow rapporteurs how a good report can be made and has achieved a maximum of 466 amendments, for which I really want to thank. We know that the Millennium Goals were fine and that part of the Millennium Goals has been achieved. However, today we are facing new challenges and today we need a new programme. It is important that all aspects, both social, and economic, and environmental aspects were taken into account here and it is very important that this was some way looked at together. Otherwise, in times of climate change, at a time when resources have slowly worn out, we need a really new approach. Tomorrow is the day of the fight against violence against women and that is why I am pleased that you have included this component of gender equality and caring for the under-advocated gender.  In any case, poverty needs to be eradicated, all 28 countries need to have a common position, and that is why I share a common opinion with you that Europe will also be safer if we eradicate poverty and it will help that Europe can work better together.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to congratulate Mr Stier, who, together with the shadow rapporteurs, has managed to articulate a position not only majority in the Committee on Development, but also focused on solving very acute problems suffered by humanity. In 2000 the international community took a courageous step. A step that has proved, over time, effective, in the sense that millions of people have come out of poverty, and other health-related objectives, with education, with the provision of medical or health services have also made decisive progress. But this step is still insufficient. As noted, more than one billion people still live in poverty and yet during this time, inequality has also increased. From a social conscience point of view, inequality is sometimes more bleeding than poverty. In 2015 humanity has two challenges. Respond with another fifteen years to the fight against poverty and exclusion for the defence of human rights, for support for governance, to include women cross-cuttingly in all objectives. In fact, without the presence of women, these objectives cannot be achieved.  We will also face the fight against climate change. Thus, Paris, New York and also Addis Ababa are in 2015 three key moments in which the European Union has to remain the global player, the most committed player to these objectives. Fifteen years is, more or less, a generation. We need to ensure that in 2015 we guarantee the generation that then takes over that the scourges of poverty and inequality will have been left behind, and that they will disappear definitively by 2030.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: The world is different than it was in 2000 or five years ago. The more we are aware of the growing global interdependence, the greater our co-responsibility for global development. The SDGs only make sense if they are followed by a globally coordinated action.  I am pleased that my rapporteur, My Colleague Stier, has strongly emphasised in his report that we need to tackle poverty and other challenges at our roots. Charity concerts, resolutions and occasional political visits are not enough. A common strategy and political cooperation is needed based on respect for human dignity and group identities and their human and natural resources.  Both must, however, aim at improving government in crisis areas and globally. The European Federation is negotiating partnership agreements with several important players in the world.  It would be right that the new agreements should also reflect the will to share responsibility for global development and, above all, a commitment to work for lasting peace. I propose that health should now be one of the priorities of strategic partnership cooperation with greater ambition.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to thank and congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Stier, our shadow rapporteur, Ms Elly Schlein, and the Committee on Development for being able to reach, with this report, a strong and comprehensive agreement on the key topics that we need to address in the post-2015 global framework. Secondly, I welcome the fact that in this report the core issue of climate change has been recognised as one of the main underlying structural factors that lead to poverty and inequality in the current world. Because of climate change, the world will have to face the consequences of struggles over scarce resources, conflict, violence and hunger. Rising sea levels endanger entire regions of the planet, and, if we do not act now, there will be an increase in natural disasters, which will continue to cause the death and suffering of hundreds of thousands or millions of people, often in developing countries, who, let us be clear, are the least responsible for climate change. Therefore, I really welcome the fact that the framework will be universal and the burden is, hopefully, going to be shared. In order to achieve our post-2015 development goals, we must make sure that our development – not only of developing countries but also of European countries – is going to be sustainable. We must find a way to promote growth while reducing greenhouse gas emissions by changing energy patterns. We must work closely with NGOs and private organisations which strive to put these principles into practice. It is still within our power to combat the threats that menace the success of our post-2015 development goals. My hope is that, at the upcoming climate conferences in Lima and Paris, the EU will be the leader in the global effort to tackle climate change in advance of the UN Summit in September, since unmitigated climate change creates costs for global development that we absolutely cannot afford. Using all means, we have to save the world. It is all we have.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr. President! Everyone must have the right to live in decent conditions. That is why, in 2000, the international community adopted the so-called millennium objectives, which should be achieved next year. Progress has been made in some countries, but we are far from being able to say that we have been successful everywhere. On the contrary! Efforts must continue to be made after 2015 to create good living conditions for as many people as possible. Cooperation in development policy among the Member States of the European Union must also be strengthened, but also improved and coordinated by the Commission. On the other hand, we must also demand that the political leaders in the so-called developing countries shoulder this responsibility and work for their citizens. Poverty reduction and sustainable development can only be achieved if the opportunities offered by the developing countries themselves are also exploited and those responsible there do not plunder the riches of the countries and the profits end up in the pockets of less. We must also demand this at this point.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Mr President, as this Parliament’s long-standing rapporteur on corporate responsibility, I had the huge privilege of being part of the European delegation at the Rio+20 summit for sustainable development and there, with many others, put the argument about the green economy – that capital accounting should be reflected in national economic accounts, something which was pioneered by the United Nations Environment Programme – and advanced the argument, in common with many from within the business community, that that should apply to companies as well in terms of sustainability reporting within their own accounts. We made huge progress at Rio. The global corporate sustainability reporting coalition pushed this agenda. It was not us politicians; it was not NGOs and trade unions; it was investors, 77 of them, representing some two trillion dollars of assets under management. We got paragraph 47, encouraging sustainablity reporting, but now I see the outcome document of the open working group in what is prepared for next year in the UN, and it simply, once again, says: encourage sustainability reporting by business. We pushed that agenda in Rio. I appeal to the Commissioner to push and adopt this agenda. Business wants us to do it. We cannot get sustainable development without business itself being sustainable. France and Denmark, two of our Member States, have been friends of paragraph 47, the paragraph in that previous outcome document. Let us build on what they are doing and let us give European support; and, if we do so, companies will, as we have done within Europe within our non-financial reporting directive, adopt these practices. But we do not just want to see it happening in Europe; we want to see it happening in the world.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Mr President, thank you for this. I would just like to emphasise how important it is for the European Union to support such a human rights-based approach, and Mr Stier's report is an absolutely shining example of how this can be done. I would particularly like to appeal to you to remember that the rights of women and girls, including the right of women and girls to prescribe their own bodies, are also a fundamental human right, and I would draw attention to paragraphs 28 and 58, that this balance is not changed, as recorded in them.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, important steps have been taken in recent years towards achieving the Millennium Development Goals. Unfortunately, however, in many countries the goal remains a long way off. Even where progress has been considerable, it has not led to the elimination of very high levels of inequality. Some groups, such as the inhabitants of slums or peripheral regions, religious minorities and people with disabilities, continue to be excluded from achieving these objectives. I believe that understanding the reason for this exclusion is essential to ensure that the commitment to development is more effective and inclusive in the future.  The feelings of exclusion and alienation that come from this situation can undermine social cohesion and generate disorder and conflict. I therefore believe that the global development framework should reflect a greater awareness of the fundamental importance of inclusion: no person, regardless of ethnicity, geography, disability or race, can be denied universal human rights and basic economic opportunities. The European Union must guide the process of defining the new development framework with a balance between the eradication of poverty and the fight against inequalities, with particular attention being paid to inclusion, which I hope will be an essential element in the implementation of the framework.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, at a time of enormous economic and technological development in world society, there are EUR 1.2 billion in aid to the European Union. our fellow human beings living in extreme poverty. At the same time, 250,000 people across the globe have a fortune of $30 trillion. more than a third of world GDP. According to a recent UBS report, the trend to make the rich richer and the poor poorer continued in 2014. The total net wealth of the rich Americans increased by 6%, the rich Europeans by 8.9% and the rich Greeks, in Greece of the troika and the memorandums, by 16.7%, from 60 billion euros. $70 billion to $70 billion. That's a lot of dollars. At the same time, EUR 3.9 million has been used to support the development of the European Union's financial people in Greece live below the poverty line, i.e. 35.7% compared to 27.6% in 2009. Poverty is therefore the result of specific policies - the policies of the memorandums and austerity.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: Mr President, society is constantly evolving, but problems such as hunger and poverty remain the same at all times, which is why the European Union's efforts to help eradicate malnutrition and hunger, as well as the phenomenon of 'hidden hunger', should focus in particular on children and women who are breastfeeding.  On the other hand, achieving the objective of 'zero hunger' cannot be achieved without including the concept of food and nutrition security as the top priority for the new global development framework and its correlation with efforts to promote sustainable agriculture, increasing the productivity of agriculture and fisheries, reducing food loss and waste, transparent management of natural resources and adapting to climate change.  In this context, we need to recognise the specific needs of women working in agriculture in terms of food security, because women are often the driving force of small properties that take into account traditional land use rights.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, the goals set by colleague Stier's report must indeed be pursued. Their universality, which a colleague rightly points out, is important if we want to live in a just world, but I hope that we will not try to achieve them through universal methods, that is, that we will respect the differences between world societies, nations and cultures. Universal solutions have so far not borne fruit in our own backyard, so it would be flawless to expect the opposite effect on the global stage. Examples of children starving in one of the Croatian schools or families thrown out on the street because of the cruel Enforcement Act are becoming a daily occurrence in my country, despite Croatia being a member of the European Union.  I am therefore particularly pleased that my colleague is proposing to apply a new development framework to member states in order to reduce visible inequality between them as well. I welcome the emphasis on the importance of the private sector, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises that are carriers of economic growth, and in our country are literally broken by excessive levies and administrative burdens.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Mr. President, I am committed to adopting the Millennium Goals that will advance democratic standards, guarantee dignity for all, and defeat hunger and war. As a person who stands for equality for all, I think it is necessary to ensure a fairer distribution of wealth with a view to combating hunger and poverty. It is therefore important to redirect the financial support we provide to sustainable development and to encourage the creation of those jobs that come through a sustainable economy, that protect employees and their social security and that protect the environment.  In particular, I would like to mention the importance of investing in rural development in order to ensure a level playing field for the village's population as those in the city. These people need to have the same standards, but they also have to have a job, and one of the best models of self-employment is agriculture. Farmers produce food and that is why they are important to us, and the issue of fair distribution of food is a matter of policy. That is why we need to be politicians who will have a sense of the needs of the people and who will know that it is imperative to protect everyone's human dignity and allow every human being to be born and to come true throughout their lives.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, the world is more intertwined than ever before in the most diverse ways possible, from what is positive to what we are talking about today which is of course extremely difficult and negative. First of all the fight against poverty, above all what european values are that we do not want to impose on others, but we want to simply offer as something that we all share together here, namely gender equality, the rule of law, generally speaking human rights and all that we know is essential for our continent.  I want to believe that Europe can remain a leader in all these policies that are essential for our continent, but only on one condition: If Europe is really going to have one vote in both the European Commission and the European Parliament and the Member States. If that's not the case, we're hardly going to stay leaders in that field.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: We can boast about the small steps taken in this or that area, in the quality of life of the populations of our planet, however, if it is certain that progress is admitted in one area, we find a profound degradation in the quality of life of people in many places on the planet and, in particular, here in Europe, where hunger and misery gain ground every day. However much specific progress that is announced, nothing erases the paradox of having today this enormous scientific and technological potential, which well used would arrive perfectly to feed and dress decently all humanity. This report being accurate in the complaint, fails to diagnose and does not prescribe substantial for the cure of the patient. In fact, nothing is said about the heavy responsibilities of neoliberal policies implemented around the world from the 1980s onto the 1980s. Nothing is said about the responsibilities of large multinational companies or the large military and industrial complex. We agree with all these objectives, we think it is not possible to devise a clear strategy for its fulfilment without changing our model of society, where the interests of great capital overlap with the well-being of peoples and where political power overlaps with economic power.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, let me first thank you for this fruitful debate and your valuable input into the post-2015 discussion. I have noted your views on various issues that are so important for the 2015 process. Gender equality, migration, the environment and human rights will most certainly be some of the key priorities in our work. This also goes for education, sustainable growth, health issues, and domestic, international and private-public interlinks into development policies. The EUʼs development policy is a cornerstone of our relations with the wider world. It works alongside and shapes a range of policies from foreign affairs, security and trade to the environment, agriculture and fisheries. As such, it gives us considerable negotiating power in the discussions ahead. The EU is the world’s leading donor and its most open market for exports from developing countries and, in particular, the least developed countries. I believe that this gives us a very powerful and influential voice in the post-2015 discussions. The high degree of convergence between the EU position and the open working group report is one manifestation of that influence. Your report is an important contribution from Parliament to forging a clear and strong EU position. I trust that the Council will deliver sound and effective conclusions in a few weeks’ time. But we should not stop there. The global partnership required to implement the new Agenda will need supporting actions from all stakeholders, including Parliament’s. An effective review, monitoring and accountability mechanism will be essential. I see a significant role for parliaments here too, in helping to hold us to account on progress and in encouraging greater ambition, particularly in ensuring that all citizens can indeed benefit. Together let us bring the weight and influence of a coordinated EU position into the intergovernmental negotiations. In September next year the United Nations General Assembly will come together to agree on a new development framework for our time. Let us show how strong a voice the EU can have and how united it can be and influence our partners to reach the best possible outcome.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Rapporteur. - Mr. President, this discussion seems to have shown me that the report has one broad support from various political groups. I would like to thank in the end all those who contributed to the discussion, but especially the shadow rapporteurs, because indeed, without their constructive approach in this work, it would not even be possible to draw up such a report that enjoys broad support and sends a very clear message to the Council, which must now draw conclusions in December that will define the position of the European Union. I am so sorry that there are no council representatives here with us now.  However, I would like to highlight good cooperation with Commissioner Mimica. I think that this cooperation will also be extremely important in this coming period, of course in the implementation of this position that the European Union will take. I will not, of course, refer to everything that has already been said today, however, I have to correct some inaccurate allegations from lawmakers mainly from the far right who have now left the chamber, but who complained that there is no word at all in the report about the fight against corruption. Of course that's not true. This was mentioned by Mr Aliot who voted against the report on the committee as well. However, the report has a whole section dealing with this themo, and specifically paragraph 29, very specifically on the fight against corruption. Therefore, before the reviews go, the document must be read.  Of course, what I have said before in my opening words, effective development policy is actually an antidote against all radicalism, both in the world, both in our environment, but of course this also applies within the European Union. So maybe I can understand why some far-right positions don't want to support this approach and this kind of document. What is important is that the European Union speaks with one voice, that we have one strong position in the negotiations that will take place in 2015, and that in this way the European Union remains one strong force for good and for sustainable development.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 25 November 2014 at 12.00 p.m.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on delays in the start-up of cohesion policy for 2014-2020 by Iskra Mihaylova on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development (O-000082/2014 – B8-0042/2014).

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: author. - Mr President, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, I wish to express my concerns at the delay in adoption of the operational programmes (OPs), the delay in implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020, as well as the risks we are facing that 2015 will be another zero year. Implementation of cohesion policy was supposed to start in 2014, but the programming stage is still far from being finalised. Only a limited number of operational programmes have been adopted and, according to the latest information available, only just over one hundred programmes will actually be adopted by the end of this year. Moreover, for programmes not ready for adoption by 31 December 2014, 2014 commitments can only be preserved by rebudgeting uncommitted amounts from 2014, in accordance with Article 19 of the Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation. However, this implies a revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework, on the basis of a Commission proposal with the Council’s agreement and Parliament’s consent. As a direct consequence, there will be a significant delay in the actual start-up of project implementation. However, 2014 should not be a lost year as regards investments from the five European structural and investment funds. In this context I would like to table the following question. In the light of the above, can the Commission indicate the exact state of play as regards the adoption of the partnership agreement and operational programmes and the estimated timeframe for starting their implementation? What were the main problems encountered, and by which Member States? What is the Commission’s current position regarding the treatment of commitments for operational programmes co-financed by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the Cohesion Fund, which will not be adopted by the end of 2014? Why has the issue of rebudgeting uncommitted amounts from 2014 in 2015, through revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework, not been brought to Parliament’s attention until now? What can be done to ensure that the revision process goes smoothly and is finalised before 1 May 2015, as specified in Article 19 of the Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation, so as to avoid losing uncommitted amounts from 2014? In this connection, does the Commission envisage taking any measures to facilitate implementation of the operational programme? The Commission should analyse all possibilities in order to ensure that all operational programmes resubmitted after the deadline of 24 November 2014 are taken into consideration in order to conclude the inter-service consultation by the end of the year and be treated as ready for adoption if they fulfil the quality requirements. We are aware that the rebudgeting of uncommitted amounts from 2014 in 2015, under Article 19 of the Multiannual Financial Framework, implies a revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework by 1 May 2015, which, even if it is technical, has to comply with the multiannual budget procedure: a Commission proposal for revision of the MFF, consent by Parliament and unanimous adoption by the Council. Moreover, it should be stressed that, in order to have the operational programmes adopted, a corresponding draft amending budget covering the commitment appropriations for 2015 also needs to be approved. This implies, in the best-case scenario, a delay in actually starting to implement those programmes until mid-2015. What measures does the new Commission plan to take to speed up programming in order to ensure that the adoption of OPs takes place as soon as possible without lowering their quality? Can the Commission provide information as to how the situation with regard to unpaid bills from the 2007-2013 programming period affects the adoption of OPs and the start of the new implementation period?

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I am very pleased and honoured to be here as Commissioner for Regional Policy and I thank the Committee on Regional Development for this important question, which allows me to explain where we stand with our cohesion policy programming and the measures that we need to take in order to guarantee smooth and fast completion of the process. Let us start with good news. As you know, all partnership agreements and 39 cohesion policy programmes have been adopted to date, including 24 investment for growth and jobs programmes where REGIO is in the lead, 14 where employment is in the lead, and one European territorial cooperation programme. The first rural development and maritime and fisheries programmes will be adopted by the end of this year and the rest will follow in 2015. As you said, the 2014-2020 legislative package for cohesion policy was adopted very late, in December 2013, six months later than the corresponding package in 2006 for the period 2007-2013, so this late adoption of the multiannual framework and regulation left no time for preparation of the programming period starting on 1 January 2014. Expenditure is eligible as from 1 January 2014, which means that Member States do not need to wait for the programmes to be adopted. They can start implementation of activities in sectors that are not subject to debate with the Commission. In fact, in many regions, calls for proposals and project selection processes have already started, and some of the operations to be supported are already ongoing.  Of course, procedures and projects that started before adoption of the programmes will need to be confirmed and validated by the monitoring committees, once established, and will need to comply with the regulation.  You ask about the main difficulties encountered when discussing operational programmes with Member States; and, of course, circumstances and issues are different from one Member State to another, so I do not think it would be appropriate in such a limited time to give details. But to summarise, I can say that the debates were mainly on a handful of recurrent issues: the insufficient logic of the intervention foreseen, and therefore the need to strengthen the link between needs and challenges, identified inter alia in the country-specific recommendations, and between results to be achieved corresponding to indicators and actions to be supported; the lack of concentration of investment priorities, the fulfilment of ex ante conditionalities, and finally, of course, the importance of having robust strategies in place to enhance administrative capacity. Moving to the question of the programmes that still need to be adopted, we consider that more than half of all cohesion policy programmes will have been adopted either by the end of the year or under the carryover procedure by March at the latest. In order to preserve the 2014 commitments for the remaining programmes, and those that will not be ready for adoption by the end of this year, the Commission intends to present a revision of the MFF by early February 2015. We hope that we can count on the European Parliament and the Council to help us secure early adoption of this MFF revision and the related amending budget before 4 May 2015. The internal Commission procedures have also been streamlined in order to allow them to carry over as many programmes as possible. However, the Commission will not compromise quality over speed. The programmes which set the framework for investment for the next seven years must build on solid strategies so that European taxpayer can be assured of getting the most effective use of their contributions.  Finally, I would like to assure you that the backlog of 2013 unpaid claims for cohesion policy – and I know Mr van Nistelrooij will ask me about that – will not affect the start of the new period, as the newly adopted programmes have immediately received pre-financing. I had an intense discussion with the Commissioner for the Budget and with other colleagues in order to find a solution for these unpaid claims. However, approval of the third amending budget for 2014 and the budget for 2015 by the budgetary authority as foreseen by the Commission remains essential in order to reduce the amount of unpaid claims for the 2007-2013 period for this and next year. Thank you very much once again and I am looking forward to hearing from you.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – This week is the first meeting in full order in Strasbourg, the first plenary session with the new Commission. You were all but one of them. Also a good time to put the finger on the investments.  On Wednesday, the Commission will release its Juncker plan for 300 billion. New money, all fine. But today, with this question, we are putting the finger on what we already have, on those budgets that have already been released. And then we are talking about the European investment structures, investment funds in the order of some EUR 360 billion. And then there's an important pain point.  The pain point is - and you also went into it - that this is not getting going quickly enough. You say: 'The formal framework was not approved until the end of 2013'. I'm a little different about that. At the end of 2012 we had all this whole framework together, we had a code of conduct, in which we had agreed with the Member States that they would now really come up with programmes and that they would behave in the spirit of the code of conduct. Well, it has indeed taken some time and that disappoints us. Therefore this question and also this concern. We must ensure that it is transferred in a timely manner, as you have already indicated. We want the exact track book, the exact dates for that from you. Finally, this week is indeed about those investments, that investment plan. Wouldn't you like to go into the following idea: we have so many instruments, we have made risk sharing, public/private partnerships, as well as revolving funds possible in the context of our resolutions. Do you not think that the Juncker Investment Plan is an important basis for doing even more in order to create a smarter, greener and more competitive Europe with jobs?  I'd like to hear that from you. And I'm not going to go into the pile of unpaid bills this time. Because you have reassured me in that regard. I suspect, moreover, that in December the Member States will come up with a very large pile of bills which they have saved up. And then it will turn out that the unpaid bills will be significantly higher at the beginning of next year than we now think. But I'll give you the benefit of the doubt.

name: Kerstin WESTPHAL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. How can we really speed up the procedure? Above all, how can we ensure that the funds for 2014 are not lost? In this context, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to make it quite clear that the unused funds for 2014 cannot simply be put somewhere else in the future. I know there are great desires. But there will be no relabelling with us Social Democrats and Social Democrats. Because, as I said, cohesion policy is an investment programme, a recovery plan. And 2014, ladies and gentlemen, must not be a lost year of cohesion policy. We can do that here in this House, and the European Union certainly cannot afford it! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: blue-card question. – Ms Westphal, as a Social Democrat, you were asking basically for more money, or for more money to be spent sooner. Can I ask you where you think that money comes from? Does it, for example, come from the European Union taxpayer, and do you perhaps think that there are any costs when that money comes from the European Union taxpayer?

name: Kerstin WESTPHAL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Well, on this issue, I assume that you will of course know what the Committee on Regional Policy is doing in this House, but also for Europe. And, as I said, all the money that we spend through the Committee on Regional Policy and through the European Parliament in the Member States – they are not spent differently, they have an effect on the ground. They work in jobs that work in quality of life, but they also work for young people, for all those who are there. That is why it is necessary to take money into our hands and not only to manage it, but to use it properly and decently, as we proposed in the cohesion package.

name: Andrew LEWER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, there is a tradition in the Westminster Parliament that in one’s ‘maiden speech’ one makes reference to and pays tribute to the area one represents in a way that is relevant to the question in hand. In line with that tradition, as this is my first speech as an MEP the appropriate reference is the UNESCO World Heritage Site – the Derwent Valley Mills – which runs from the City of Derby, through Amber Valley and into the Derbyshire Dales, a site I was proud to chair for four years. It stands to benefit from ERDF funding and yet could be beset by similar sorts of EU-sourced problems that this question seeks to highlight: bureaucratic delay and not setting out parameters clearly. What I speak in support of tonight is a cross-party question, and that strengthens the concerns expressed. It also demonstrates my political motto in action: ‘Work in the world as it is as well as working to change it’. Support for this question does not tie me, my delegation or my group into support for all aspects of regional and cohesion funding. As my hero, the great Samuel Johnson, put it in 1753, ‘Every man amuses himself with projects which he knows to be improbable, and which, therefore, he resolves to pursue without daring to examine them.’ Well, we are at least going some way towards examining them through this question, and I hope our actions will have a beneficial effect for funding partners, especially our key friends in local government, for recipients and, most important of all, our taxpayers, as I was delighted to hear Commissioner Creţu refer to in her comments already.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Mr. President, respected Commissioners, colleagues and colleagues, we must put our hand to our hearts and in some way say that European cohesion policy is in a crisis of sorts. In doing so, I do not want to discourage our Commissioner, Mrs. Creţu, whom I have trusted and trusted and which I hope, together with Mr Juncker, when they present their plans, on Wednesday we expect a significant presentation, that they will convince us that cohesion policy will also turn into the success of this Commission, because I will also see the success of european union cohesion policy in this mandate as my success in working in this Parliament.  But the fact that we have significant lags in unpaid bills is something that significantly upsets our fellow citizens, organizations, institutions, NGOs. Also a dramatic lag over operational programmes is something that raises doubts about the success and realization of cohesion policy quickly, in the coming months, in the coming years.  That is why I want to make every effort and I will personally do everything if there is anything I can to help impose cohesion policy as one of the key policies of the European Union, because I am convinced that Europe can be built in the best way from the ground up, from cities, from regions, from our countries to the European Union. I believe in this principle of subsidiarity, and this is where regional and cohesion policy is the key policy. In this context, I hope that with this issue today we will encourage discussion, but also that in the end we will all come together with satisfactory solutions.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Commissioner Creu, I share with you your desire not to sacrifice quality for speed. But still, we are faced with an urgent problem: putting cohesion policy on track to achieve the best possible success in the 2014-2020 programming. Beforehand, we must now find a real solution to the problem of the 23 - perhaps 28 - billion euros of lack of liquidity which, if not resolved immediately, will tomorrow result in a situation that can no longer be managed.  In Milan, at the informal Council of Ministers, we and my colleague said that we have misunderstandings about the irresponsibility of the European Council and we are counting on the European Commission to move forward very quickly on this issue.  There is an urgent need to find all the flexibilities within the Commission so that operational programmes can be validated before 31 December 2014. Otherwise, we will take the risk of creating new blockages within the European Council for their reallocation in 2015. I just want to stress one point: there is nothing to say that the technical adjustments that will be needed will be easily obtained from the European Council when we see how little the European Council is showing to find solutions to this 23 billion problem.

name: Monika VANA
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to join all the previous speakers in stressing the importance of this issue, not only for the European Parliament and the Commission, but primarily for Europe's citizens. As has already been said, cohesion policy is one of the EU's most important investment instruments, and I do not need to explain its importance in this House, particularly in the crisis. We must finally invest out of the crisis, instead of further saving into the crisis. I would also like to stress the importance of cohesion policy, particularly in achieving the crucial Europe 2020 objectives that we have all set ourselves together: from the fight against poverty to active labour market policy, from education to fairer distribution. It is precisely here that Europe must not hesitate any longer! It is a truly alarming situation how many operational programmes have still not been adopted. This cannot really be explained to the citizens of Europe – together with the unsustainable state of unpaid bills, which have really reached scandalous proportions, and the fact that the investment plan, as much as it has now been discussed in the media, is still an empty phrase. I hope that will change over the course of the week when it is presented here. We have to do something and we have to act. And I would like to join in all the appeals here, not only to the Commission, but also to the Member States, to the regional level, to all, to work together here to finalise the operational programmes as quickly as possible, so that the funds are released to the citizens in 2014, but also to make the impact of the unpaid bills, for example, on Erasmus students, the scientists of Horizon 2020 and the other stakeholders clear.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by quoting some data from Eurostat and DG REGIO. Between 2008 and 2013, public investment across the European Union fell by 20% in real terms. In some countries such as Greece, Spain and Ireland, the decline has been close to 60%. Without cohesion policy, investment in the Member States most affected by the crisis would have fallen by a further 50%. The role of the European Structural and Investment Funds is therefore all the more essential, not only as a result of the cuts made by the Member States to reduce budget deficits.  On the other hand, it is all the more serious, precisely in the light of the above, the serious institutional and financial stalemate caused by the delays in cohesion policy already mentioned by my colleagues. It is all the more serious precisely because it is the size of the territory that is at the expense of it, and therefore ultimately the citizens of Europe, who have been dramatically affected by the crisis and who are looking with increasing disaffection at the national and Community institutions. I come from a region, Puglia, and from one part of Italy, the south, where very serious inefficiencies have already occurred, with the result that the Funds have been dispersaled. Adding to this very worrying picture of delays in the start of the 2014-2020 programming would have devastating consequences. I can therefore only share the concern expressed just a few days ago by the President of the Committee of the Regions, Michel Lebrun, when he warns that unless there is complete – and I would add fruitful – rapid and effective cooperation between the Commission, the Member States, the regions and the cities, European investment could reach the territory too late. I also regret having to stress, as my fellow Members have already done, the seriousness of the European Union's eur 23 billion of outstanding accounts in cohesion policy alone, with obviously very serious repercussions on the beneficiaries of the funds.  Having read with curiosity, but also and above all with great concern, the Commissioner's statements made at the General Affairs Council, when she said that she expects cohesion policy to contribute to the EUR 300 billion investment plan proposed by Juncker, I therefore ask: could the Commissioner please clarify exactly what she said? Does Juncker intend to transfer some of the EUR 350 billion already earmarked for cohesion policy?

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the launch of the cohesion policy for 2014-2020 is already a failure. While many operational programmes will not be adopted until the beginning of 2015, the European Union is facing very serious payment delays for projects undertaken during the previous mandate from 2007 to 2013. These delays in payment obviously cause great difficulties for some of our local authorities and businesses. Even with the cohesion policy, which is supposed to translate into action the principle of solidarity that drives you, the European dream turns into a financial nightmare.  These delays in the adoption of operational programmes are due, in part, to the very low absorption capacity of some Member States which cannot effectively spend the financial windfall promised to them. The scandalous transfer of the management of European funds from the State to the regions also has the effect of delaying the launch of the cohesion policy. Worse, the implementation of the 2014-2020 programming by the regions or assimilated communities, which therefore have a weaker administrative structure than their respective states, will result in longer deadlines in the assembly and financing of eligible projects. As such, the Sivens Dam case gives us a bitter taste of the future calamitous cooperation between the European Union and local authorities. This project has been totally sloppy and illegitimate to the point that the European Commission is now threatening a withdrawal of European funds. In this case, the Action of the European Union is a blatant failure.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: The accelerated absorption of cohesion funds, mainly in the field of environmental and transport infrastructure, in 2013 and 2014 has been a major boost to the construction sector, which, for example, has largely helped the country's exit from recession in the Republic of Slovenia. The same has happened in many other Member States, where cohesion funds accounted for 20, up to 80% of all public investment.  New road connections, high-speed rail, new water works, wastewater treatment plants, rural broadband, business zones, technology parks – these are cohesion policy measures which, in addition to the free movement of people, goods and services, the common euro currency, have also proved to be key building blocks of european ideas, the European Community. And that is the kind of Europe our citizens and citizens want. We have been reminded of the Group of the European People's Party for a long time that we already have a huge backlog at the beginning of the new cohesion period 2014-2020, which will also result in a drawdown failure in 2014. The consequences will also be in 2015 due to possible complications in the adoption of operational programmes and therefore less pumped resources.  We therefore expect and appeal to the new Commissioner, to the European Commission, to take cohesion policy as a key policy in its programme and to eliminate these backlogs of operational programmes as soon as possible , in cooperation with the Member States. Do this, do something for a common Europe.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, it is a pleasure to meet you on this side of the Chamber. However, the delay in validating operational programs is a serious anomaly that disrupts the start of programming for the multi-year financial framework. As legislators, we take our share of responsibility and will contribute effectively to finding solutions. Having said that, I would like to stress to you that there are two elements. Firstly, the importance of this delay in the programming of the implementation of cohesion policies is that it weakens all the projects seeking public funding throughout Europe, all those investments that Europe so desperately needs in the face of the crisis. If some Member States are more concerned than others, then let us say so, not to denigrate but to help. If the Commission's technical assistance is insufficient, then strengthen it to meet the quality requirement you have raised. This is the Union's priority: to achieve projects and investment as quickly as possible in our Europe in crisis. Secondly, this difficulty in regional policy echoes the budget payments crisis. On 17 November, the European Parliament was forced to abandon the budgetary conciliation procedure, as Member States were unable to present a viable response. However, it is the regions that pay the heaviest price of this budgetary cavalry. The European Commission must propose an emergency mechanism on cohesion policies. Which regions are most affected, what is the amount of unpaid bills in each region, what are the needs?  These two crises have a violent impact on the economic activity of our European territories. Commissioner, we know your unwavering commitment to cohesion policy, so tell Mr Juncker - before he comes to announce his long-awaited recovery plan on Wednesday - that our Europe needs public investment more than ever, that regional policy is part of it and that if we do not fix it, it will be futile to consider other mechanisms than ever before. , which would be bogged down in the shifting sands of sluggish public investment.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Last year, after three years of negotiations, we completed work on a package of new regulations for cohesion policy, thus entering the next programming period. Armed with the instruments of the European Union's largest investment policy, we have launched a new budgetary perspective. Its main objective should be to stimulate economic growth, sustainable development and to reduce disparities between the rich and the poorest countries and regions of the European Union. This is, after all, the basis of the philosophy of European cohesion policy. Meanwhile, it appears that countries and regions are today showing serious delays in launching the 2014-2020 programmes, which, I do not hide, is of increasing concern. Yet the experience of 2007-2013, when the procedures for agreeing entries in documents took a very long time, should be a sufficient warning to all of us.  It is important that the Member States maintain a balance between the developed regions of the European Union and the poor in their proposed operational programmes. In my country, Poland, it is m.in with a programme for Polish Europe. At this point, I would like to thank the Commissioner very much for the words she said during her last visit to my country, that this government should pay much more attention Polish the regions of Polish East Europe, one of the poorest regions of the European Union. This is a significant difference in approach to the problems facing eastern Europe, such as lack of communication accessibility, migration, poverty and high unemployment. I believe that Poland will remodel projects under individual operational programmes so that a large part of them will go to the eastern regions of my country.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the European Union. The implementation of the new regional policy should be more effective and simpler – that was the big stated goal. The reality today looks devastating. We have heard of open invoices, we have heard that half of the operational programmes have so far been approved. What I find even worse, however, is what I keep hearing when I am on the ground, that regions and municipalities have largely not been involved in the implementation or development of the partnership programmes. Economic and social inequalities between regions are growing again, despite EU support, and we are talking here about means that should actually eliminate these inequalities. I believe that decisive action by the Commission is needed here. A final word on the proposed 300 billion investment package: it would be unacceptable for us to see this investment package at the expense of the Cohesion Fund. That would be a sham.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for We are aware that the inquiry is not critical, but is intended to be a process that triggers a certain process, it is intended to be a kind of "facilitator". We are aware of this, firstly, that the regulations have introduced quite complex procedures. I am referring to the relationship between the Partnership Agreement and operational programmes. On the other hand, there are discussions about the 2015 budget, which unfortunately do not end positively for the time being.  I would like to appeal to the Commissioner to use this inquiry as a pretext for the European Commission to be more informed about the programming process. Increasingly, there is a growing belief within the Union that the European Commission is specifically slowing down certain activities. It slows down because there is no money to pay invoices. It is therefore important to inform the programming process very precisely and accurately, as the beneficiaries in particular will interpret your behaviour as a deliberate activity. I ask you to understand this inquiry and give you full information.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: Commissioner, not coincidentally, in this Chamber almost all colleagues say the same thing and, instead of adding a list, repeating everything that has been said here, I will say the following. Around 100 operational programmes will be adopted by the end of 2014 and a small number of operational programmes will benefit from the 'carry over' procedure. This creates a very complicated situation for implementing the policy.  Please, therefore, on behalf of my group and on behalf of those benefiting from investment policy, which is the true essence of cohesion policy, to do everything that is up to your authority and the European Commission so that we can first identify the means to assess the documents submitted by the Member States more quickly (this is imperative) and , then to be able to talk between the Member States, the European Commission and the European Parliament to amend the multiannual financial framework, in order to bring to date these delays which are in fact burdening the much-needed funding to our communities.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Mr President, the Member States and the European Commission can so far be responsible for the consequences of the obvious delays in the start-up of cohesion policy for this period, but I think we would be wrong if we merely assessed or analysed only those delays. If the Member States and the European Commission have failed at all, it has been, so far, at least, in the design and management of cohesion policy. It was the great principle of the European integration project. One of them, at least. And today we are witnessing an almost unprecedented social, economic and territorial fracture in the Union. Let us then look at how to get closer to citizenship when deciding to transpose and manage programs. Let us use better, much better, the principle of subsidiarity, without unnecessary filters to regions or cities or, as in our case, to stateless nations. Thus, as Martina Michels said, cohesion policy will be not only simpler, but much more effective.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Mr President, Commissioner, cohesion policy, made up of the European Social Fund, the ERDF, the Cohesion Fund, contributes to inclusive growth, sustainable growth, smart growth, helps to achieve the objectives we have set, in employment, research and innovation, helps to strengthen our competitiveness, improve our skills, contribute to combating climate change and also contribute to the fight against poverty.  Cohesion policy, in addition to meaning economic, territorial and social cohesion, also means competitiveness, job creation, wealth creation. It is therefore unacceptable that it can be seen as an adjustment policy.  What is happening is that the European Union budget is in serious need of payments, and it is unacceptable that cohesion policy – the one that best allows internal solidarity, the one that contributes to economic growth, to territorial and social cohesion – should be penalised.  The Council in 2013 stopped paying EUR 23.4 billion. This year we run the risk of having a higher amount, and no one notices. How does someone who advocates growth, jobs, how does someone who has a policy and instrument for growth not pay what they owe, does not pay what they have authorized?  This is very easy to resolve: the commitments that have been made with the citizens of the European Union are fulfilled.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: Thank you, Mr President, the situation we are facing is indeed very serious and I thank you, Commissioner, for even proposing in recent days the creation of a working group to help countries in a particularly difficult situation. 2015 threatens to be a year almost zero for the use of European funds. With great concern, we Bulgarian Socialists point out the risks: that the programmes stop in countries that cannot afford to offset eu funds through their national budgets.  The danger of bankruptcy leads to job losses. The lack of timely funding will lead to the blocking of farmers, small and medium-sized enterprises, municipalities and infrastructure projects. Suspended payments and unapproved programmes threaten to turn cohesion policy into a policy of distance and strengthen Euroscepticism, as people do not recognise the European Union as a partner.  So far, only one operational programme has been secured for Bulgaria. Please dispel the doubts that the slow approval of the programmes is being made in order to save european Union funds. I expect the European Commission to assess all programmes already deposited by the end of this year. We insist that in cases where purely technical adjustments are concerned, the relevant programmes should be approved as a matter of priority, as well as that the deadlines be shortened: at the beginning of next year, the reprogramming and approval of the others should be carried out indeed within shortened deadlines.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has We are asking the Commission today, while at the same time we should have asked the Council our questions. But the council bench is empty. It is the leaders of the Member States who are always the first to refer to the Structural Funds and cohesion policy as the most important instruments for growth and employment in Europe. For the past year, the new multiannual financial framework was to take effect and the new funding period was to be implemented. Instead, not even many foundations have been laid, and the Council is blocking the budget. Ladies and gentlemen, trust is being lost! Regional cohesion policy has always been an important brace for the cohesion of the Union. Anyone who damages them is putting an essential link between the European Union at risk! The Commission must not now agree to delay, but must take an active lead in creating the conditions for the implementation of the new funding period. She is sure of the support of the majority here in the European Parliament.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Welcome Commissioner, although at a rather difficult time for the European Union. I would like to remind you that we are not in this situation of very serious delays because there have been delays on the part of the States or your predecessor, but because agreement has not been reached on the multiannual financial framework until a very serious delay, a situation which, as you have seen, is being repeated for the budget. So the crux of the problem remains that of the financial resources and the delays that this entails in the management of the programmes. Since, as all my fellow Members have said, these investments are essential to restart the European economy and in many countries it is now the only public investment that drives, of course also through cofinancing, a little investment by the States, which are, moreover, reducing them a lot, I ask you to work as quickly as possible, including, of course, on quality, to try to close this game within a reasonable timeframe. Thank you very much and I hope that you will really try to give us positive results.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to underline once again what many of the previous speakers have already said: we need a budget. This is certainly nothing new, but we are moving towards a worrying situation, particularly with regard to cohesion policy 2014-2020. Even in the so-called best case scenario, the investments to be supported by cohesion policy will not start until 1 May 2015 at the earliest. However, this depends entirely on whether an appropriate amending budget is adopted to cover this expenditure. I would now like to know: how will the Commission manage the liabilities of 2014 if there is indeed a reallocation of structural funds that were not used until 31 December 2014? How can we ensure that the promotion of operational programmes starts as soon as possible, without, however, disregarding their quality? We must give the Member States the opportunity to use the funds they have at their disposal, especially the funds for cohesion policy.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, you have been in office for twenty-one days, so no reproach can be made. But cohesion policy is not a hundred days of grace. And it does not have them, above all, because there is a cumulative delay and because cohesion policy is sometimes the only instrument to deal in some places, in some territories, with the problems of crisis, employment and development. We are talking a lot about the need to mobilizing resources to meet the challenges we face in Europe. But we have instruments in our hands whose delay is generating consequences that affect regions and cities. There's an unpaid problem that's already been talked about. There are co-financing problems that are on the table.  Cohesion policy cannot wait. The Commission, the College of Commissioners, must be applied to respond to the challenges before us. And, of course, to respond to the challenges—more in these times of crisis—is to respond to the deficits that cohesion policy currently has.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to address the Commissioner with a few comments. You have heard in this House today, as you did at the Commission meeting, full support from all Commissioners so that there can be a line that gives you strength, both within the Commission and in your relationship with individual governments. The delays to which reference has been made, and which we are all aware of and which are obvious, are delays on which we must work very clearly. We need precise answers, including on the re-budgeting of 2014 under the 2015 budget. We also need to clarify how much the Commission's EUR 300 billion plan can have an impact and negatively affect the use of these resources. This is an issue that cannot be ignored. Thirdly, I would also like to entrust you with a further very important request, from which we determine many of the resources to be spent, and it is that of the ability to have an impact on investment on the release of the stability pact count of the share of national cofinancing that blocks the majority of investments, should we continue in this direction. I would like to add one final point: the speed and quality of expenditure are two fundamental and decisive elements to which we must look very carefully, trying to focus the use of resources on infrastructure and strategic interventions to the full, avoiding a division on several fronts.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: Commissioner, Mr President, we all agree that the European Union's cohesion policy is one of the areas with high impact on citizens. However, with a long-term application cycle, most of the results desired by citizens and local and regional authorities are not visible until after the end of the programming period.  How does the Commission consider that we can have a more strategic focus of resources on key priorities in order to achieve the results desired by both the Member States and the Commission, but also to be able to give an adequate response to the delays in the start of cohesion policy in the period 2014-2020?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I can of course only join my fellow rapporteur's request for clarification on this crucial subject for the socio-economic development of the European Union. The added value of the Structural Funds is no longer to be demonstrated for the regions of our Member States. Their actions enable us to take in-depth action to enable Europe to remain competitive at the global level. As a result, thousands of sustainable jobs have been created, particularly in so-called development-delayed regions. To take a specific case, I can give you the example of the commune of Farciennes, in Belgium, where I come from. Thanks to the contribution of the European Structural Funds, my municipality has been able to develop a major strategic economic project that will create more than 3,000 jobs. The Ecopole, since this is what it is all about, is a unique economic activity park in Europe focused on sustainable development techniques. This is an investment of 75 million euros on a 300-hectare wasteland, which would undoubtedly not have been possible without the contribution of the European Structural Funds. I could also tell you about Charleroi airport, which is used by many MEPs. In 2013, it was the third most friendly airport in the world. Its implementation, with the help of Europe, has created more than 2,000 jobs.  You have heard it, Commissioner, I think that today I really want to press the European Commission to position itself on the various operational programmes handed down by the Member States and I think we need concrete answers on the delays, on the timing of future projects, on the pace of funding, on the arrears and the available rate and the possible link with the 300 billion plan.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Mr President, I would like to address three issues a little more, albeit in a minute: acceleration, dialogue and cleanliness. However, it has also been raised here that one of the reasons for the delays, perhaps one of the reasons for the delays in the programmes, is that the European Commission does not have sufficient financial resources, so I would like to ask the Commissioner for her clear guidance, is there money or there is no money? But, on the other point of acceleration, the Commissioner has already made a few indications, a few indications as to how it can be accelerated in the Member States. I hope that this will be done not only here in Parliament, but also that the competent authorities and organising institutions will also receive these guidelines. And very often the subject of dialogue falls victim to acceleration, and I hope that the Commission has the means, and indeed I ask: do it have the means to take into account whether, in the course of acceleration, the dialogue is not left behind among those involved? And finally, cleanliness. Unfortunately, in my own country, Hungary, acceleration always results in politically soaked and generally close to the government receiving the funds. Can they control that? Thank you very much for the opportunity!

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Thank you, Chairman. Dear Commissioner, in discussions in Parliament the Commission assures us all along, and we have agreed that it is not only quality that matters, that speed is also important. Looks like we're both out of control.  N+3 for 2014 is now turning into N+2 and even less than that, and when it comes to quality, many adopted documents are not well related to the key recommendations of the European Semester and do not provide a clear answer to the question of how their implementation will ensure the development, especially of apostrophied cities, because studies have shown that urban areas are not well covered in strategic documents , as well as rural areas, job creation, fostering entrepreneurship. Along with these issues, as far as unpaid commitments are concerned, the question we have to ask is how the European budget is managed and how to address unpaid commitments.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, the questions asked require immediate answers because poorer members cannot wait. Cohesion Policy is the most important tool in the fight to reduce inequalities between Member States, and any delay in its implementation is a blow to the foundations of this community, which is tasked with ensuring stability and security for those less developed.  In addition to the inefficient administrative apparatus and the often lack of a long-term strategy of national governments, less developed members cannot stand the scum of European authorities, but count on their determination and strategic reflection. This was absent, for example, in the division of Croatia into two NUTS II regions, which placed the least developed eastern part of the country in the same statistical region with the richest northwestern part, thus depriving those in need of the necessary funds for development.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Mr President, I will certainly keep the time. Commissioner, I would like to ask, given the importance of cohesion policy for economic growth, which is undeniable, whether the opening up of the Multiannual Financial Framework may also pose a risk to beneficiaries of cohesion policy support, as Member States may also want to open up the question of the level of their commitments precisely to the 2014-2020 budget period. Can there also be a situation where the debts remaining from 2007 to 2013 are covered by the budget of this new period 2014 to 2020? Is it really true that the European Commission is delaying the approval of operational programmes because it does not have the money to pay its old commitments? I would like to ask you these questions.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I would like to speak in my own language because I would like to be as clear as possible. There were so many problems here and I would like to tell you: I would like to tell you that I am truly aware of the importance of adopting operational programmes as soon as possible, especially for countries where our funds contribute more than 50% in public investment. I would like to tell you that, from the very first day of work as European Commissioner for Regional Policy, I have sent a letter to all the ministers of the European Union states, telling them that it is necessary to step up our efforts for the benefit of, of course, the citizens, and I have had the opportunity to meet with all 28 ministers from the Member States in the Business Council for Cohesion Policy. I am grateful to the Italian Presidency that, for the first time, it has inaugurated this framework for debate between the European Commissioner for Regional Policy and all ministers in this area. I have seen that many of you have thrown all the blame for these delays on the European Commission. Of course the European Commission has its share of the blame, but I remind you that it is a shared responsibility. The principle of 'shared responsibility' is all the more strong here, within the framework of cohesion policy, because those who draw up the programmes, the ones implementing them are the Member States, the regions, the local authorities. As Mr van Niselrooij said, the Commission anticipated the delays and launched discussions on operational programmes as early as 2012, but we must recognise that the adoption of the Multiannual Financial Framework and the new legislation for European funds had a significant impact on the ability of Member States to submit quality programmes in 2014. Firstly, speed and success depend to a huge extent on the Member States, because they must take into account the Commission's observations, produce the necessary documents. I'll come to the European Parliament on 8 December. I will be here in the European Parliament, in the Committee on Budgetcontrol. I will be responsible for how the taxworkers' money is used. You ask for a more simplified and efficient way, but at the same time control of taxworkers' money is also needed. I hope that we will be able to adopt not 100, but 150 programmes by the end of the year.
