However, I want to assure you that we have made this 'task force' for countries with a low absorption of European funds, because they are countries – I have also said in the Council, and in the press conference – where money has really been pumped without seeing many results in people's daily lives.  This is the case, for example, of southern Italy and I am ready to go there, to talk to the local authorities, to the regions. If you could tell me how can I approve a programme for southern Italy, which has not even been sent to the European Commission? How could I? I cannot take responsibility for the adoption of these operational programmes without being assured by all the services of the European Commission that all the requirements that you have asked here by the legislation you have adopted are met. Because we are responsible, as you said, for the efficient use of public money.  And we're having this discussion. We had a discussion in Poland. All the operational programmes were concentrated in Warsaw and we asked them to make an effort to lean on eastern Poland, which is an underdeveloped region, because our intention is to bridge the gap. For Bulgaria, I did everything I could. We have unlocked the money that has been locked in for the environment since 2012 because, practically, the conditions have now been met.  It is the Commission's duty to suspend payments, to discontinue payments when there is a suspicion or when OLAF comes into action. We expect the Member State to meet the conditions and, when the conditions are met, we have restarted the money for the operational programmes, where payments have been interrupted. Indeed, we have this ongoing debate with the Member States, and I am glad that I have had the opportunity to talk to ministers, because absorption is necessary but, as I said, we must not take absorption for the sake of absorption. We need to make sure that these operational programmes meet the needs of citizens and the most vulnerable groups.  I want to assure you that you will have a partner in me. I have informed you and I will inform you on a permanent basis, I will try to come up with a roadmap and the answers to the problems you have raised for the operational programmes to be adopted in 2015. We hope to adopt them as soon as possible after the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework, and I welcome the Latvian Presidency's intention to address this subject with the utmost priority.  Summing up, at the moment we have all the partnership agreements adopted. Out of 310 programmes provided for 14 were adopted by my predecessor, Commissioner Hahn, in 2014-2020. Since we took office we have adopted 25 operational programmes in 21 days and I hope that by the end of the year we will adopt 148-150 operational programmes. Please understand that it is almost physically impossible to adopt all operational programmes, and that is why I have asked the Member States to prioritise which are the most important and, of course, which are ready. We're doing everything we can.  One last topic: I'm just as worried about unpaid bills as you are. All I said was that for the period 2014-2020 pre-financing was passed on, but I know, like you, that the amount of unpaid bills will increase. It's a problem that needs to be solved. I raised it in the college, I spoke to Commissioner Georgieva, because it is not a problem that the Commissioner for Regional Policy can solve on his own.  Thank you once again, please do not hesitate to raise any issues in your region, and I want to assure you that I consider myself the lawyer for the regions and citizens of the European Union in the College of Commissioners.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 27 November. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Daniel BUDA
text: Written. – The signing of the partnership agreements for the 2014-2020 programming period kicks off cohesion policy funding. But the objections raised by the Commission create delays and postpone the start of this process, so that only 10% of the total operational programmes submitted have been approved so far. In the case of Romania, the Commission specifically commented on the inability to learn from the experience of the previous period (2007–2013). The Commission's objections relate to the lack of sound argument for the continuation of investments and their correlation with existing ones.  We need to understand that economic growth objectives are closely linked to the coordination of sectoral policies, and a strategic approach that pursues a coherent distribution of investments leads to development capacity building and contributes to increased competitiveness. I stress the importance of continuing investment through the financing of growth poles. Polycentric development models have demonstrated their functionality by creating jobs and contributing to the economic development of the regions. We must also ensure that the final objectives of these investments are linked to social inclusion programmes for disadvantaged groups.  I believe that the main priority for Romania is the adoption of the 2015 budget, as the national contribution to beneficiaries is essential for starting investments until Community support is obtained.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Written. Delays in launching the new operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 are causing growing concern. Yet the 2014-2020 programmes represent an investment in the future and an investment in Europe. Cohesion policy is entrusted with the crucial task of reducing member states' territorial development gaps with regard to europe 2020 priorities and objectives. Unfortunately, the delays that are accumulating in the programming of the European Structural Funds 2014-2020 risk disrupting the Community machine and, above all, numerous regions in the main beneficiary countries, starting with Poland, Spain and Italy; with the serious danger of having to reopen the debate on the financial perspectives that were laboriously approved a year ago. The Commission must first speed up programming and equip itself with stricter control instruments. There is also an urgent need for concrete quality control of performance, so that cohesion policy resources are better allocated, ensuring a better combination of the various funds and an optimal impact of investment, in order to respond concretely to the pressing needs of European citizens.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Written. We are faced with a clear delay where only a limited number of operational programmes will be adopted by 2014 (around 100 out of over 300). For Italy, we hope that a good number of operational programmes can be ready by the deadline of 31 December 2014. It will be very important for the Commission to do its utmost to speed up its internal procedures for approving OOs as well so that the inevitable use of the revision of the multiannual Financial Framework under Regulation 1303/2013 is launched quickly and is completed on time, ensuring that the entire budget for Italy scheduled for 2014 is available in full and on schedule. I hope that the Commission, together with Parliament and the Member States, will be able to find the most appropriate response in order to overcome the long-term challenges by effectively speeding up the implementation of programming. We are waiting for the Commission to give us more information on how it intends to launch the task force that it announced yesterday, informing Parliament of the future agenda. In view of the new 2014-2020 programming, I am sure that concrete and transparent measures will be taken, not punitive decisions, such as the reduction of public co-financing, but rather initiatives aimed at creating constructive synergies between the different actors acting on the ground.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. – The North West region of England benefits from millions of pounds in European funding which goes to support projects around the region; the next round of European Structural and Investment Funds is worth more than £1,132m to my region between now and 2020. These projects create jobs and grow our economy. However, I am extremely concerned that by scrapping Regional Development Agencies, and putting in place 39 Local Economic Partnerships (LEPs), which are not democratically accountable, the UK Government has put the region's funds at risk as the role of LEPs has not been adequately explained to the European Commission and they have not been proven as fit for purpose to oversee and dispense European funding. Any gap in funding as a result could have a serious and negative effect on excellent projects across my region. European money has been key in ensuring the development of my region and I do not wish to see any delays in this vital investment. I urge the UK Government and the Commission to agree the programme for funding as quickly as possible.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: Written. – Commissioner Corina Crețu has made important clarifications on this subject. I am convinced that, through her efforts, the cohesion policy programmes will fully re-start as soon as possible. Cohesion policy is the most effective mechanism for generating economic growth and development. Thanks to European solidarity, Europe can develop together and areas with development deficiencies can narrow the gap slower faster. To do this, we need a transparent and effective cohesion policy to combat the messages of populist parties. In this respect, a clear analysis of how the funds are used is needed.  I welcome the decision to allocate, for example, more funds for the construction of motorways in Romania. It is a priority area for Romania, and prioritising the allocation of funds must be a key point in the European Commission's effort. We need a wider dialogue with beneficiaries and partners in order to identify these opportunities. We need to better prioritise projects based on the effects and quality of the programmes. In this respect, I support the increase in the budget allocated to the Cohesion Funds and the steps taken by Commissioner Corina Crețu to make their performance more efficient.

name: Olli REHN
text: Written. "I come from Finland, which is a great country. More than 338,000 square kilometres contain many stunning areas. In the current difficult economic climate, keeping all regions alive can be challenging, but in the longer term it is of paramount importance. Cohesion policy is an investment policy whose importance is even more important in more difficult times. This is also known in Eastern and Northern Finland, where cohesion policy plays an important role in regional development. It has been great to see how, for example, investments have been made in green growth in North Karelia. It is therefore very regrettable that the implementation of cohesion policy is currently on the back. It is of paramount importance that the programmes get under way as soon as possible. Cohesion policy plays a very important role in achieving the 2020 targets set. I am glad that the Member States have also just recognised this and Commissioner Cretu also promised to do everything possible to speed up the process. However, the question arises as to whether there are countries that do not fully understand the potential of cohesion policy, otherwise it will be difficult to understand the procrassation. Kicking forward time limits must not become a habit. Everything must now be genuinely done to promote the smooth implementation of cohesion policy. Europe must be put on a path to sustainable growth and cohesion policy must be harnessed to make an important contribution to this.

name: Milan ZVER
text: In writing .– European funds for some Member States, including Slovenia, in times of crisis are virtually the only development resource to realise important investment projects and help create new jobs. This is why any backing in the implementation of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 will make the European economy all the more dangerous at this time. By the end of the year, we should adopt all partnership agreements and operational programmes, but, according to the visible and heard, there are grave doubts that all operating programmes will be ready for adoption by the European Commission by the end of the year. If this happens, there will be long delays in the implementation of cohesion policy, and our entrepreneurs and, as a result, EU citizens will suffer. In the future, I would like to see greater proactivity and accountability in the planning, proposing and adoption of partnership agreements and operating programmes. At the moment, however, the most important thing is that the Commission, together with the Member States, do everything possible to prevent this black scenario from occuring. Immediately after that, we urgently need to address the delays in EU payments that we are facing this year. This is unacceptable, but it is another topic.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the oral question to the Commission on export controls on dual-use goods by Bernd Lange on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (O-000081/2014 – B8-0040/2014) (2014/2869 (RSP)).

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Author. - (DE) Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work on I am not only a person, but also chairman of the committee of authors. In this respect, the committee has put this oral question, and I think rightly so. If you look around, you have to say that the European Union's arms export policy is like a Swiss cheese, especially when it comes to dual-use goods. We know that, in the case of heavy goods vehicles, it is indeed still possible to differentiate whether this is one that is more likely to be used to transport machine parts or one that is used to set up a rocket launcher. When it comes to software and IT and communication technologies, it will of course be more difficult. It can be astonishing when an activist in London receives an e-mail about conditions in Bahrain and this e-mail contains a Trojan, which in the future ensures that her smartphone is intercepted, that all texts she types into her smartphone can be read by third parties. We have this kind of use of surveillance software and information and communication technologies everywhere to spy on human rights activists, political opponents, people who defend diversity of opinion and fundamental rights. I therefore believe that it is time to take a closer look. After all, it is not only that activists in other countries, where it is said that there is a terrorist regime or a regime that is not committed to human rights, use these dual-use goods of software and information and communication technologies, but also people in Europe are monitored by forces from third countries through this software. This is not only a problem in Bahrain, where European software has been supplied, it has also been a problem in Iran, where an entire control network has been set up with European technology, or in Syria. The Libyan secret service has bought technology from a company that advertises openly with the slogan "Best and easiest to monitor". Even this company says that it has about 50% market share in the Middle East. And if you look a little further, Ethiopia is a customer, Nigeria, Uganda, Qatar – these are all things that don't really fit into the concept of a value-oriented European Union. That is why it is a step in the right way that software Trojans and network control systems were included in the Wassenaar Arrangement in December 2013. But this has not yet resonated in European politics. However, I would like to see an EU system that guarantees that software and information and communication technology cannot be misused and can fall into the hands of those who monitor their populations and people in a way that we do not accept. Incidentally, this also has strategic and safety implications for us, because this software can of course also be used in the digital context in Europe. And that is why, Commissioner, the three questions: what about the uniformity and enforceability of legislation in the field of dual-use? We know that dual-use goods are basically all approved, because we do not seem to have any inhibitions at all to deliver these goods to areas where armed conflict is taking place. Or the second question, the question of control. After all, it is not acceptable to check only ex-post and not to decide in advance which goods to export to which countries. And then, thirdly, we must also find a procedure that is as unbureaucratic as possible and ensures manageability, not ignoring economic interests. In this respect, three sets of questions, and I look forward to your answer.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, thank you so much for raising this extremely important but difficult question. As you know, the European Union is a major producer and exporter of dual-use items and a significant actor in counter-proliferation export controls. Export controls are key to the competitiveness of our exporters – approximately EUR 14 billion of control exports – and this is also crucial to our and international security. Our export control regime has been gradually strengthened in the last decade. It has robust provisions and it provides a solid legal and institutional foundation. It has been a model for many third countries, but of course the world is changing and it cannot remain static. It needs to be re-evaluated and upgraded so that we can face the different challenges that Mr Lange, and others, made reference to. So we need to have a modern control capacity for the coming decade and beyond. I share your concerns over the problems which have been raised and the concerns regarding export of surveillance technology. It can be misused in violation of human rights, and we have taken action to address this very important issue. We have, in record time, prepared and adopted, in October this year, a delegated act to transpose into EU law the multilateral decisions taken under the Wassenaar Arrangement to control intrusion software and Internet monitoring equipment. This is a very important first step. Furthermore, the export of surveillance technologies is an element – and a very important element – of our export control policy review. As you know, the Commission published a Communication in April last year in which we set out some concrete options under a human security approach, to fully take into consideration human rights as a new dimension of export controls. For example, we suggest clearly establishing human rights as a reason for control and possibly denial of export. We want to act quickly, but it is, of course, very important to calibrate our response carefully. We need to identify exactly which items pose a threat to human rights, to our security, and to select effective and targeted controls while being aware that some of these items also have a legitimate use. We should not lose sight of the risk of seeing products exported from third countries replacing our rightful exports. This would harm our competitiveness and offset the positive effects on security, or on respect for human rights, and that is why we have now launched an impact assessment of various options to modify our export control regulations. We also need to take into consideration how we can develop synergies between the different security trade controls. That is only one instrument that we have. We could, for instance, consider restrictions on the export of surveillance technologies by targeting specific countries. This is covered by sanctions under Article 215 of the Treaty. As you know, the Communication has also outlined a vision for a risk-driven model to generate modern control capacities of EU needs for the future. It sets out concrete options to enhance the effectiveness of controls and minimise distortions in competition, and this would improve the level playing field both within the EU and in our relations with third countries. We could, for instance, promote a shift to open licensing: controlling transactions in companies without delaying export and keeping ex-ante controls only for the most sensitive items or destinations. This would reduce delays and costs associated with controls while providing a high level of security. Finally, I share Parliament’s views that the very specific technical nature of these products requires the mobilisation of highly specialised expertise. We are therefore mobilising experts from all over the EU to conduct regular technical examinations of technological developments to ensure that our controls are up to date. We are engaging with stakeholders, particularly civil society organisations and industry representations, so that they can provide important input to this process. In that regard I would like to emphasise that the private sector is, of course, the first line of defence against proliferation and other associated security threats, so we need to develop a real partnership with the private sector.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Controlling international trade in products that may have dual applications is a very difficult task these days. This is not only facilitated by the ease, despite many barriers, of control, of supervision of trade, but above all by the development of research, techniques and technologies, which are intended to have a very universal application, and in fact only it is up to the users to actually use and use them.  Another issue worth highlighting is the increasing share of international trade in small and medium-sized enterprises. This is a very beneficial process. Companies in this sector are an important base of economic systems. Therefore, they should not be subject to excessive controls and bureaucracy.  Dear! Respect for freedom and the building of international security require the creation of legislation and specific procedures for a modern and effective system of control over trade in dual-use products and technologies so that these products are not used for unlawful repression of citizens or aggression against other states or nations. All this must also apply to modern scientific thought, research and development. However, in doing the right thing, care must be taken not to harm the economic development of the Member States of the European Union, the competitiveness of Europe and the important internationalisation of our small and medium-sized enterprises. Thank you.

name: Jörg LEICHTFRIED
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Sometimes politics is tedious. If you look at certain areas of detail, it is even more tedious. I remember well that when I started to deal with dual use things, not as first, but certainly as one of the first in this House, i had to explain what it was. Few people know what dual-use items, if you can call them that, actually are. The media didn't deal with it, it was uninteresting. And things that are uninteresting always provide an opportunity for groups that profit to do relatively unrecognized things. If you take that up, it's harder. But I can also remember how I then meant: Well, but these dual-use items are actually weapons, are as dangerous as weapons, are something where you have to be careful, as Mr. De Gucht looked at me a lot and said: Well, he doesn't really know, but that's quite another thing. That is why I am glad, Commissioner – and I have listened to you very carefully now – that you think that these are things that need to be addressed, because there are some problems. The first problem is that there is currently no equality of competition in Europe in terms of exports. I will speak English because I can see the Earl of Dartmouth over there, partly hidden behind his nice flag. We have nations that have quite strict rules on exports and other nations that do not have those rules. I think that the United Kingdom, for example, is a nation where they have quite strict rules and they care about those rules. There are other nations in Europe where that is not the case. So it is a disadvantage for the United Kingdom if we do not have European rules. I do not know, maybe the Earl of Dartmouth would agree with that. This is a situation that is bad. That is why this should be changed. We need uniform European rules. Of course, we must also pay attention to what falls under these rules. Until now, we always have the principle that there is a list, and anything that does not appear on the list can be exported. Is this the right approach? I do not know. Perhaps we need a catch-all approach in the future. The second is, as you have also mentioned, the question ex-ante and ex-post. Yes, of course, ex-ante costs more, but ex-post may cost lives. We have to weigh that up. And perhaps human life has to be weighed more heavily than the cost of business. The third is the large area of software. Slowly, as a European legislator, we are succeeding in bringing the software sector into these dual-use items, also in connection with human rights violations. This is extremely important. Most Leopard II tanks exported to the Middle East have not yet cost lives. European software technology has already cost a great many lives. We must be aware of this.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: Mr President, I was specifically mentioned by the President – in a very friendly way, by the way – and it is customary, under the rules, that I have the opportunity to respond for 30 seconds or whatever it is.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: It is customary for the chair to take the decision. It is also customary that if a speaker who waits for the blue card but has speaking time in the very same debate uses his or her speaking time to address whoever addressed him first, so your colleague Anna Fotyga now speaks on behalf of your Group.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for your Countries such as the United States, Canada and Morocco have also covered space technology under sanctions imposed on the Russian Federation. The Union has decided otherwise. Our sanctions programme does not include the European space programme, as a result of which Airbus's Galileo commercial satellites were launched three times this year by Russian Proton and Soyuz rockets. Moreover, they were taken out in a disgraceful way, in one case they hit the ground, in the other two were taken into the wrong orbits. Do you think that this state of affairs should be blamed on the legislative flaws in the export control system for dual-use goods or on the lack of solidarity or political will of the Member States with regard to Russia's aggression against Ukraine?

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, today we were reminded of what is at stake in this debate that has been ongoing for too long: ethical hackers investigated how our EU institutions were attacked by malware that steals data. The malware presents itself like software that we use every day or enters through the Belgian mobile phone carrier – software not hardware – using zero-day exploits. Experts have compared Regin to Stuxnet, with which Iran’s nuclear facilities were attacked a few years ago, and found it in countries like Russia, Mexico, Saudi Arabia and Iran. And while it is popular to look to China or Russia as perpetrators of such sophisticated attacks, the research published today leads me to believe these systems may well have been made in Europe. Even if developed for intelligence services, technologies proliferate very easily. They get smaller, faster and cheaper every day. Imagine the non-state actors active in this unregulated market. All over the world these technologies help in violating human rights and harming our critical infrastructure and sensitive data. This billion euro market in digital arms could be the biggest boomerang we have ever seen. The irresponsible vacuums in export legislation need to be filled, and systems that facilitate mass surveillance and hacking into peoples’ devices without legal basis and without their consent should be much more closely scrutinised. We need transparency and accountability as well as licensing requirements, a level playing field and certainty for companies. I am interested to know whether the Commissioner will present a positive or negative list of countries or technologies and how adjustments to crisis will be made. Will you, Commissioner, work with a catch-all mechanism? I think it would be a good idea. I also urge for impact assessments in the R&D phase to know earlier on what dangers systems can pose, while allowing researchers to do their work. We need future-proof and smart legislation very soon, and much more than what the Council adopted on Friday. Waiting longer is, frankly, irresponsible and dangerous.

name: Ska KELLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the There is still a great deal to be done on how Europe intends to proceed in the export of goods that may look harmless but can be used to persecute, for example, human rights activists. The main objective must be to protect human rights and the safety of people – here in the EU, but also in third countries. It is not enough to inspect the goods only when they have long since ended up in the wrong hands. Then it is too late. We need ex ante, not ex-post controls. As technology evolves, we too must evolve and our legislation. There is no point in removing modern surveillance technologies, because they can do great damage. I call on the Commission to address this issue now. We need a proposal now, in 2015. This is not a purely technical matter, it is about how we protect people and how we protect human rights.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, in view of your earlier exchange, I have to say that I wonder why it is that establishment politicians who call themselves liberals are in fact – and in reality – always so thoroughly illiberal. As President, you obviously take your cue from the Chair of your group, Mr Verhofstadt, whose currency, as we saw earlier on today, is almost always abuse and not – as it should be – debate. Anyway, I would like to take the opportunity to respond to Mr Leichtfried’s very graciously-put question – and I would just point out that the distinguished colleague on my right is not a member of my group, as the President seems to think. Perhaps you will be better informed next time you chair a session of Parliament, even a comparatively minor and technical session like this. To respond to Mr Leichtfried, the United Kingdom applies its own judgement on these matters in determining what we should, or should not, export, but I – and other people in the United Kingdom – entirely respect the right of other countries to apply their own judgement on what should or should not be exported. We do not believe that this should be subbed out to the unelected Commission. The significance of dual use is that, in order to export anything on the dual-use list, businesses and exporters in the United Kingdom need to get permission from the Commission first. To be clear, despite the charming introduction from Chairman Langer, the question is misplaced. The dual-use framework simply gives yet more power to the Commission to designate what can or cannot be exported. The United Kingdom is a leader in world trade and has been a leader of world trade for hundreds of years. The dual-use regime is just simply unacceptable.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Thank you and I do apologise to our colleague Anna Fotyga for assuming that she might actually be part of your group.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: Mr President, exports of items and technologies that could be used in the wrong way, namely to curb and control civil initiatives and suppress human rights, have become an increasingly serious challenge. The dual-use items often help to spy on human rights activists and are vital to keep independent opposition under control. Today there is a clear need to make sure that export control mechanisms are up to date and more efficient. This means effective cooperation with researchers and also the private sector. Such cooperation also has to address the growing threat of the intangible transfer of technologies. I would like to commend the Commission’s review of last April on the export control policy, which outlines the main shortcomings and proposes strategic lines for the future. I think the meaning of today’s debate is to support and speed up a legislative proposal to update the existing dual-use regulation. It should also provide incentives for all Member States to join, for example, the Wassenaar Arrangement, because behind the  widespread misuse of these dual-use items there is a much deeper issue at stake – the credibility of the EU, which is above all based on common values and fairness. The continuing practice of dual-use items ending up in the hands of repressive regimes is distorting and undermining our moral foundations in favour of pragmatic, short-sighted gains to expand one’s markets by any means. There is an urgent need to establish an efficient embargo on exports of dual-use goods and technologies to countries that are targeted by the EU sanctions, for example Russia, from where the items in question can be transferred to separatists. Finally, my question to the Commission is: what steps will be taken to ensure that cybersecurity will be effectively addressed in the process of international exports of dual-use items?

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Colleagues, again can I remind you to stick to your speaking time?

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Malmström, today, more than ever, it is essential to address the issue of dual-use products, on the one hand because of the European Union's new tendency towards activism and other players to intensify economic and commercial relations, on the other hand because of the growing strength and organisational capacity of terrorist groups and, finally, because of the speed of technological development, which is difficult to accompany with adequate rules. That is why it is essential to pay the utmost attention to the Commission's regulatory effort on dual-use products, and the legislative proposal must in any case be speeded up. But we want to use this opportunity to highlight some concerns, some that have already been touched on. First of all, account must be taken of the need to eliminate all threats arising from the misuse of certain products, but at the same time we must avoid a distortion of the market leading to a loss of competitiveness of European producers for the benefit of others whose regulation is less transparent. Secondly, restrictions must be based on stringent controls both ex ante and ex post, and action must be taken at the same time to minimise the barriers that still exist in the European market, identifying the most effective measures to support control action for the most sensitive areas. Finally, my question is: how can convergence on common standards be promoted globally, because this is the way to make the European Union's action as effective as possible?

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the We are talking about surveillance technology, and dual use is in many cases quite euphemistic, because very often it is quite clear what it is all about. This is just a single use option. Every Thursday, when we meet here in Strasbourg, this Parliament deals with human rights violations all over the world. In the vast majority of cases, we will find that surveillance technology has been used there, which often also comes from the European Union. We need an ex ante view in these cases, where civil rights and human rights are at stake. We need a positive list, and a positive list for both countries and products. Mr Lange, you have asked very legitimate questions. You were right to complain that european union citizens are also victims of third-country intelligence services. But, Mr Lange, what do you expect from a European Union that not only exports goods, but also supplies the data of its own citizens freely to third countries in the form of passenger data, in the form of bank data?

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul I received answers to several of the questions I was going to ask at the Commissioner's introduction. I would therefore like to focus more on what is not regulated today and the work that is going on to update the regulations. I would like to make sure, for example, that monitoring equipment, which is not included today, will also do so in the future. The sale of telecommunications systems is, of course, completely uncontroversial to some countries, but it can be a complete disaster to others. It may be the same with some consulting services. We must therefore introduce a system that looks not only at the product as such, but also at the recipient country. Is it a democracy, respectfor human rights, is there a risk that the country will end up in a conflict internally or externally? That can change very quickly, as we saw, for example, at the Arab Spring. We must also learn from the mistakes we made, where several EU countries have actually sold both armaments and surveillance equipment to North Africa and the Middle East. Follow-up deliveries then continue. It is important for the EU to live up to its core values of human rights and democracy, even if it is sometimes not to the benefit of industry. People's safety must always take precedence in these cases, so I hope that the Commissioner's proposal will go in that direction.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, dual-use products are those products for civil use that can also be used for military purposes such as chemicals and remote surveillance instruments, avionics components and so on. For example, a harmless air navigation guidance system that helps pilots maintain a course can also be used to drive a bomb on its target.  Attention: we are not talking here about weapons, but about products that are born for civil use and that are therefore much more devious, because they are not subject to the same restrictions, but can also contribute to human rights violations in the world.  Unfortunately, Europe is a teacher of hypocrisy in this area too, and while the Eu ropean Union has acceded to the European Convention on Human Rights, it exports surveillance equipment, radar systems and technological components that can also be used against our own interests. While Europe is full of fine words about world peace, European countries sold chemicals to Syria in 2013, with the express consent of their national authorities – substances officially intended for civilian use, but which may have been used in the manufacture of chemical weapons. It is therefore obvious that there is a need for better control over Member States and dual-use products in order to establish, once and for all, what is legitimate to export and to whom. We must also seriously begin to regulate the export of surveillance software and technologies in order to prevent made in Europe technology from being used to file those taking part in an event or to prevent anyone from asserting their rights, as was done during the Arab Spring. The law must adapt to changing times, which is why I call on the Commission to review the rules for dual-use products as soon as possible, to include more precise definitions, as evidenced by the Council's recent conclusions, and to extend the application to software and technological products, where it is necessary, and above all I call for serious monitoring of the application of the regulation by those States that often sell as dual-use products the instruments that are real Weapons.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: Mr President, unfortunately the misuse of dual-use items, especially software and technology, may contribute to hostile military agendas and the funding of weapons production, as well as human rights abuses. As we know, more and more cases of repression carried out by authoritarian governments using EU-made technology contributed to recent updates of the Wassenaar Arrangement control list. This lays the groundwork for closing possible loopholes in the rules governing trade in these technologies. The updating of existing legislation and its thorough implementation is much needed. To ensure proper use of these goods, the European Union must control the export, transit and brokering of dual-use items as a key instrument contributing to international peace and security. It is in our own interest to safeguard EU-made software and technologies so they are not diverted from their legitimate use and to ensure that the EU’s digital infrastructure and strategic interests are duly safeguarded. The European Union is an important actor in this field internationally. As a guardian of democracy and human rights, it is particularly important in view of the policy-making and legislative role it plays in the field of trade across its Member States. According to recent studies, international efforts to control the trade in dual-use goods are outdated and need to be updated in order to keep up in the modern world.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: Mr President, there is no doubt that the European Union has as its priority the promote of democracy, the rule of law and human rights in the rest of the world. However, we do not always act with the necessary diligence in the face of abuses by governments that use for military and repressive purposes products, technologies or software designed for civilian use and which, unfortunately, can be used for the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. With regard to the constant technological developments, we have seen a number of facts highlighting the urgent need to adapt European legislation and to end the possible gaps we have in this regard. We are facing a very serious problem, with serious consequences that can still be exacerbate. I think that's what we agree on, too. And I do not think we can agree that technologies and software created in the European Union can be used by the police and repressive military regimes to contribute to the repression or violation of human rights. We need modern and flexible European legislation. You said it, it's true. And we need to correct the discrepancies that exist between the Member States. But we need it now, Commissioner. I have not heard in your speech a timetable commitment on everything that was contemplated in last April's communication. Seven months have passed and we need a firm and concrete commitment, in this Parliament, that this concrete legislative initiative will already take place.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, there is no doubt that trade in so-called 'dual-use' products must not be treated with the same rules as any other production sector. These assets need a special regulatory regime that is effective in protecting citizens, businesses and governments. This need is all the more felt in a rapidly changing world characterised by the proliferation of new threats to international security and the safety of populations.  We therefore welcome the European Commission's willingness to carry out a legislative review of the current control system. We also hope that it will be preceded by an in-depth impact analysis. We need a balanced system that takes together the reasons for international security, the protection of human rights and the need to ensure fair competition between producers at international level. In this respect, I hope that the Commission will work to promote convergence of regulations at international level.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we need stricter controls on exports of dual-use products. The European Union must ensure safety for its citizens first and foremost by creating a modern and secure system for the marketing of these products. No generic export authorisation should be granted for dual-use technologies produced by the European Union, which could be used in a negative way or even used for purposes that violate human rights. To date, exports of dual-use products are not subject to any European authorisation system and it is up to each individual State to decide on export controls. At least an ex ante notification system should be set up for the most sensitive dual-use technologies. The Commission and the Member States must commit themselves to an effort at transparency and fill the dramatic legislative vacuum that exists and strive for harmonisation of legislation.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. Chairman, Commissioner, the dilemma ahead is not really that difficult: whether we are for more profits, more profits, which is legitimate, or are we truly fully honest for respecting European values – human rights, the rule of law and all that we know is often violated in countries that are our partners and that use dual-use products.  In fact, more than that, these products can often be used against oursself, against our citizens, citizens of the European Union, our neighbours, our friends. That is why, in this context, of course, I am a supporter of thinking first and foremost about European values, about what has created this parliament, and perhaps less about profit.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, controls on exports of dual-use products are an important action that the European Union must encourage. This can also be done in the international field through mechanisms for adopting common practices, also known as export control regimes. The issue of the accession of new members to export control regimes should be examined on the basis of technical criteria and should not be a field for the exercise of exclusionary policies. In this context, it should be noted that Turkey is blocking Cyprus' candidacy for the MTCR Missile Control Regime, the Wassenaar Arrangement and the Zangger Commission. For this reason, the European Union must support the Cypriot candidacy in these export control regimes by putting pressure on Turkey.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, this is not the first time we have discussed export controls for dual-use products here. Today there is talk of the technologies and software used for communications surveillance, but we have already brought other very serious cases of military use of civilian products and technologies. And the problem is not solved only with the existing regulation or with the amendments that have been requested here today. A broader and more consistent approach is needed. We recall, for example, the joint research projects funded by the Research Framework Programme, which are carried out with the participation of Israel's aerospace industry, the manufacturer of the unmanned aircraft used in the attack on the Gaza Strip and the mass murders that were carried out there. Here too, there is a rigorous assessment of the dual civilian/military use of the results of these projects and the limitation according to the access of some countries and some companies to the financing of these projects.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for your input into this very interesting and complex debate. We all agree that we have a huge number of products that can be used for perfectly good reasons, but there are also severe risks in certain cases where they can be used for surveillance or for violating human rights. This needs to be addressed. Export control is not the only way to address this – we need to do more. I tried to outline how we have done a few things, and we are now in a very cautious, listening mood in order to see how we can update and review the current legislation. We have put forward a communication; there are some ideas. We are also listening very much to what industry says, to what Member States say, to what you say and, of course, to what the different NGOs – which are very active – say. They perfectly agree with you that a few years ago this was not an issue, but now there is greater awareness, and we should use that. Regulations have been amended, policy has advanced, people are more aware, but we also need to make sure that we have controls that are updated.  It is complicated, though. We need to make sure that we get this right so that we target what we do not want to see and do not harm European exports for good purposes. That is why we are now preparing the review. As I said, we have listened to the concerns of many different experts, and we hope that we can strike a careful balance in our proposal, which will come – hopefully – next year. We are very much looking forward to cooperation with the European Parliament in this endeavour, and we are happy to come back and report to the committee and to Parliament on how we are progressing.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – The issue of dual-use products and the lack of a comprehensive export control policy is very serious. This not only applies to technology and software developed in the EU, but should be considered in a broader context: the export of all products and/or tools that can be exposed to misuse in recipient countries that think nothing of human rights, freedom of expression or the rule of law. For example, French Hee helicopter ships of the Mistral type will definitely be justified by Russia as vehicles for humanitarian search and rescue missions, but well, he also claimed that he never visited the Crimean peninsula... Countries like this will exploit and abuse our candor and technology, to the point of imprisoning their own people or even worse: even launching an attack on their neighbors. Ceterum censeo, France will seriously regret its decision to sell warships to Russia.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the Commission's impact assessment guidelines (2014/2967(RSP)).

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, let me say how important impact assessment is for this Commission. We need to deliver on growth and jobs; we need to make sure that we do not burden our citizens and our enterprises with undue regulation; we need to make sure that we deliver what is necessary so that Europe can use the existing opportunities in the economy that we are not using today. I believe that we as institutions – the three of us: Commission, Parliament and Council – have a responsibility when we create legislation to assess whether that legislation achieves the goals it needs to achieve and nothing more and nothing less. That is why I strongly believe in impact assessment at out outset, when the Commission is preparing its work. That is why I believe we need to make improvements both in the way we do our impact assessment as a Commission and by putting the Impact Assessment Board in a position to do its work. However, I also believe that we have a joint responsibility, with the European Parliament and the Council, to improve the impact assessment along the way because, at the end of the day, what has an impact is not the initial proposal but rather the outcome at the end of the legislative procedure, and all of us know that this is not necessarily the same thing. So what we need to do – and I know that Parliament feels strongly about this and is working on it – is to try to improve the process and ensure that the three institutions do more in terms of impact assessment along the way, so that when we have the final say about a directive, for example, before it is translated into national legislation, we have a clear view of the impact of what we finally decide to do, and of how to ensure that what it does is precisely what it is intended to do and not more than that. As I said at my hearing, I have a very special interest in helping small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe to use the opportunities they have. From various studies I know of, and also through the contacts I have had with impact assessment authorities in Member States, it is increasingly clear to me that removing some of the administrative burden or undue regulation from small and medium-sized enterprises can have a catalytic effect on employment and on fighting unemployment in the European Union. Just imagine, for argument’s sake, that we can lift the burden of administration from a baker or a butcher by 10%. I am convinced that even that 10% could make the difference between a baker or a butcher being able to hire an extra hand and that same baker or butcher having to close the business because there is no time to see to all the administration. These things can yield huge results because, given the number of small enterprises in the European Union, helping them helps the growth of employment more than anything else. I want to remind you that 85% of jobs in the private sector in the European Union are in small and medium-sized enterprises. Helping those enterprises by lifting some of the administrative burden – by making sure when we legislate for them that the legislation achieves the goal we intend and nothing more than that – is a direct contribution to creating more employment in the European Union. I am dead set on this goal. I am ready to come to you and be accountable for it, but I desperately need your support because when Parliament acts in terms of impact assessment it makes a huge contribution to attaining that goal. We cannot do this on our own as a Commission. We need Parliament, and I hope that the Commission and Parliament together can convince the Council to pick up this issue too, because up to now the Council, to put it mildly, has not been very active in following suit where Parliament and the Commission want to achieve results.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work Small and medium-sized enterprises are important to us, they are the backbone of the economy, and we must not overburden them with bureaucracy. In every political Sunday speech we point this out. Mr Timmermans, your speech was also a Sunday speech, albeit with more substance and a look forward. I would very much like – and you have asked the European Parliament to do so – really start work, right now, and I would like to ask you a few questions, specifically on the Commission's internal impact assessment directives. Why is there no longer a mandatory SME test? Why is the Law Impact Assessment Body no longer so precise? Why have the Directors-General been given much more discretion as to whether or not there should be an impact assessment? These are already very specific questions. However, we would also really like to call on the Commission to make this SME test mandatory again and to take the impact assessment really seriously. Support our initiative to establish the successor to the Stoiber Group to cut red tape more independently of the Commission! We have these expert groups in many European countries – Sweden, the Netherlands, the Czech Republic, the United Kingdom – and also in Germany, independent bodies assess the competence and the bureaucratic consequences of national legislation. Why not also an impact assessment of the legislative proposals, independent of the Commission in Brussels? It is not intended to replace the Commission's work on this, let alone restrict its right of initiative. Nor do we want a mooch that interferes extensively with the legislative procedures. We want a lean panel of experts to advise on better regulation and subsidiarity. We need to prove more to people and businesses that the EU is not overshooting the mark with legislation. In doing so, independence strengthens credibility.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: on behalf of the S&D group – ... a public policy is essential to ensure the efficiency and quality of a decision. In this regard, I welcome the initiative of the European Commission and the European Parliament to discuss this issue in detail and to look for new ways of achieving them. I believe that the main objective of an impact assessment is to enable the originator to understand in detail the effects of the decision. Quantitative indicators are needed, but also qualitative indicators. We need to understand that public policies affect citizens and that the people and different social actors involved need to know why we want to implement a particular policy and what the results will be. In the current political context, the European taxpayer must be informed in detail about the rationale of public policies. He must no longer be taken by surprise by the measures taken at central level or in Brussels, and we in the European institutions must understand that, beyond the states, we must answer to the citizens. I hope that, with the proposed measures, we will ensure that things no longer seem to be decided behind closed doors. The measures adopted need to better and more detail assess the diversity of the European space, as well as the social and economic peculiarities. In this respect, Commissioner, I am convinced that you will make an impact assessment for citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, assessing the impact of European Union legislation is a very important activity which must, first of all, be carried out in the political field, because the Commission must examine whether the principle of subsidiarity is being respected. This is a very important political issue concerning the very competences of the European Union, the protection of the principle of givers of powers and the protection of compliance with the presumption of competence in favour of the Member States. This is the first element that the European Commission should consider. The second is respect for fundamental rights. These are very important issues which involve many problematic and many individual aspects. The third issue concerns the impact on small and medium-sized enterprises which really need to be taken very seriously. I will tell you, for example, what is happening in Greece, where the memorandum is being implemented and where no control and no assessment of the economic and social impact has been carried out, where we have thousands of unemployed, where we have thousands of poor Greeks. Commissioner, I want to tell you what happened to small and medium-sized enterprises, because the Commission is a member of the troika. Two hundred and thirty thousand businesses have been closed. There was a 75% reduction in turnover. Tax obligations cannot be fulfilled. 46% of small and medium-sized enterprises delay payments. If you had made an assessment of the social and economic impact, we might have had different results. We must also have an impact assessment for technological development because without technology we cannot move on to the new production model. All this must be done both at Commission level, of course, but also at European Parliament level.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, over the past three years we expected more from ‘better regulation’. We wanted a reduced administrative burden, but we kept increasing it. We wanted simpler legislation, but it has become less simple. We are not consistent, and basically we are placing more of a burden on our businesses and our citizens than we should do, without reaching or aiming for better objectives. For me, better regulation is a top priority. I have dealt with the subject in the past, both from an administrative perspective and in speaking to – and working a lot with – businesses. If you talk to them today, most of them will identify this as the number one or number two issue. I very much agree with the Commission Vice-President here: if we could reduce the administrative burden by 10-15%, we would, in fact, have GDP growth roughly 1% higher than we have today. So it is a significant issue with significant implications for growth and for employment. Now this is not an issue just for the Commission. The Commission has made progress, but it can make more. The Council – I will be blunter than the Vice-President was – has done zero. Parliament has made progress, but we need more progress. I would go so far as to say that this is an issue for an interinstitutional agreement, perhaps to be looked at in the future. I would like to see impact assessment as a key issue and as a key building block in better regulation. I would like to see independently-carried-out impact assessments, professionally done. I would like experts and professionals on board. I would like to see the highest possible degree of independence, and I would like the Vice-President to supervise all these activities. I would even like to see financial targets. Perhaps that is very ambitious, but we know that it has worked elsewhere in the world, notably in the USA, and in some Member States. Having spoken to the Vice-President, my questions are similar to those asked by Mr Pieper, so I will not repeat them. I would just say, Mr Timmermans, that your ambitions are encouraging, and we will be there to work with you. We will definitely support you, but we really want to see a tangible result, which is something we have not seen in the past 10 years.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I will try to formulate three simple thoughts in one and a half minutes. Firstly, we must be careful that the agenda for better regulation does not become a pretext for another agenda of deregulation. When I look at what Businesseurope has just done today, this has nothing to do with better regulation, it is the destruction of future opportunities for our economy through deregulation. In this context, it is also important that impact assessment remains an inclusive instrument, that we do not postpone the agenda. We must take the costs into account, but we must also take into account the benefits of regulation. We must also take into account what new markets may emerge. All this must be done in context. Secondly, this so-called group of experts, which the Stoiber Commission has proposed, is something where we should not be stumbling, but should work very carefully. I would like to point out that the representatives of consumer interests, health interests, environmental interests and trade unions in the Stoiber Group have distanced themselves from these proposals. We need to discuss it carefully. We do not need a bureaucratic de-bureaucratisation loophole, and we must not reduce stakeholder participation in such a way that only a few are heard. Thirdly and finally, it would be dangerous to exclude micro-enterprises completely from the legislation, as some in this House would like. Even Eurochambres rejects this. We should do the same.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we can only commend the work and precautions of the Commission before any legislative proposal. Indeed, it would appear that the pros and cons of policy options are carefully weighed by a rigorous examination of their potential impact. I have no doubt about the seriousness and probity of these many analyses despite the large and effective presence of lobbyists in this house.  However, I wonder about the long-term effectiveness of the method and its financial cost. Is it not at the foot of the wall that we recognize the mason? So what are the results of so much work? Zero growth, deindustrialization, programmed death of our agriculture and fisheries, endemic unemployment, loss of purchasing power, failure of the school system and initial and vocational training, uncontrolled immigration, corruption at all levels and increasing insecurity, levelling down, loss of values, I happen and the worst. However, it is true, and it is clearly explained, that each impact assessment contributes to the decision but does not replace it. The adoption of a proposal is still a political decision prepared by the College of Commissioners, presented by the Council and the Commission and voted on by Parliament. So, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, look for error.

name: Michał BONI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Small and medium-sized enterprises can play a huge role in reviving the European economy. Europe needs a new entrepreneurial spirit that m.in digital tools – because it costs less and reaches customers better. This will bring new jobs. But they must not be an obstacle to a new wave of old entrepreneurship and subsequent bureaucratic burdens. It is therefore not appropriate to exclude from the impact assessment system their impact on small businesses. Therefore, it is necessary to revise and transparent the specific guidelines of the impact assessment, to accurately describe the load test on small businesses, as well as to better define the functions, tools and possible initiatives of the independent Impact Assesment Board, included in the procedures as a whole. What does independence mean? Quality of external experts also identified by Parliament, but operating in identical standards and in cooperation with the Commission. This must be done together: the Commission, the Member States and Parliament. Parliament is important because it can support comprehensive solutions, and it can also have its experts on the Better Regulation Advisory Board. On the other hand, it can help to eliminate the burden on small businesses in individual countries. But in order for it to do so, we need our resolution and its implementation – with concrete proposals to not only improve the conditions for small businesses, but also to implement smaller ones – and then better regulation for the economy as a whole.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: Mr President, I really welcome Mr Timmermans’ remarks this evening. I think that he understands the importance and I believe that he means what he says. Impact assessments form part of better law-making – better regulation – and reducing the cost of regulation for businesses is absolutely crucial for growth and jobs. We need a regulatory framework that fosters innovation, skilled jobs and access to world markets. It is important that we recognise that the needs of all businesses are not the same. There is no one-size-fits-all, and each type needs a tailored solution that will help them. I think we, as MEPs, must make full use of the Impact Assessment Unit we have in Parliament, and we need to go further. I would like to ask the Commission specifically for impact assessments to be published when a proposal goes out for consultation, a concrete burden-reduction target and specific exemptions for microenterprises.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul Commissioner Timmermans, I would like to thank you for your support. It is with pleasure that I have noted that your focus is to strengthen the quality of European legislation. We share that passion. Our citizens and our businesses have the right to expect laws that are effective and effective. It should also be a top priority for all of us in this House, regardless of which political party we belong to. The Commission's impact assessments could play a much greater role.  I am chairman of the Committee on Petitions in Parliament. In this committee, we can contribute lessons, because we see how the legislation works and how it does not work and we can define the areas where citizens have the right to expect more.  We receive thousands of petitions that could help concretely in this work of evaluating and developing policy instruments and helping with the impact assessment work as well. Hope you handle this with high priority and seriosity. I can promise you faithful allies in this Parliament, at least especially in my committee.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, Commissioner Timmermans, Vice-President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work You have stressed in your speech today the importance of good impact assessments for growth and employment in Europe, and you also pointed out that small and medium-sized enterprises are the driving forces behind this growth and employment in Europe. I fully agree with you on this: Europe is characterised by small and medium-sized enterprises. There are over 22 000 small and medium-sized enterprises, or exactly 99.8% of European enterprises, and more than 90 million employees work in these enterprises. This means that more than two thirds of all employees in the private sector work in small and medium-sized enterprises. For this reason, it will be necessary for legislation and impact assessment to focus more on SMEs. I would support Mr Pieper's proposal to include binding SME tests back in the impact assessment, as is generally the case with the principle of think small first, with the aim of creating a business-friendly regulatory environment.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, three quarters of Europeans believe that Europe generates too much bureaucracy. This glut of standards greatly undermines the credibility of Europe and its institutions. Small and medium-sized enterprises, which account for 99% of European businesses, are the first victims, and studies show that the administrative cost of new legislation is ten times higher for SMEs than for large groups. The European Commission has put in place extremely detailed procedures to ensure that EU legislation is more appropriate, including an SME test. Unfortunately, this SME test is not mandatory and is only applied for half of the proposed new texts. Worse, the draft of the Commission's new guidelines on impact assessments does not mention it.  While a consultation on the reform of the Small Business Act is under way and in all countries, business associations and consular chambers are mobilising to respond and be heard, the Commission must not scale back its ambitions. The principle of thinking about the small first must be the rule, not the exception, if Europe is to be useful and help SMEs.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: Madam President, small businesses are the key driver of European economic growth, as we know, but we need to make life easier for them to flourish. Therefore the impact assessments are a crucial tool to ensure that the laws are fit for purpose, that they work for small companies as well as they do for big companies. However, according to the Commission expert group, currently the cost for SMEs to comply with the regulation can be ten times more than for larger companies, and this should not be the case. The Commission needs to put itself in the shoes of a small business which often has neither the time nor the resources to take part in heavy and too-frequent consultations. I would therefore very much like to know what actions are foreseen to better reach out to small businesses to assess the impact of a proposal. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: A question raised by raising a blue card. – My question goes in the direction of the need to look at where those options are where these procedures can be simpler.  In my deep belief, the area of public procurement in particular is one of those areas where small businesses have the most problems, and this is one of those areas where there is a great deal of confusion in Europe. Differences between countries. And it's right to simplify it. Does the Member agree with this?

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: blue-card answer. – Madam President, I am sorry but I did not hear the interpretation – it was in some other language.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr. Bogovic was making more of a comment. So if you want thirty seconds of comments...

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: Madam President, Mr Timmermans, first of all I would like to highlight the special importance for SMEs of an adequate assessment of the impact of European regulations by the Commission. In Catalonia, three years ago, the Catalan Government passed five laws to reduce the network of entrepreneurs and small and medium-sized enterprises, since they are the ones that often face the greatest difficulties in adapting to new legal and administrative requirements. And we must not forget that they occupy 70% of the workers in the European Union. In this sense, it is therefore essential to always keep in mind the principle of thinking first on a small scale, which we leave embodied in the small business act. We must not forget that SMEs are the true engine of the European economy, as I said, and account for, for example, in Spain, 99.8% of all companies. They are a source of employment and wealth creation, so facilitating their activity should be one of the premises that guide our political action. The Commission's commitment to periodically review impact assessment standards in order to improve them is therefore a step in the right direction, but perhaps not sufficient. In the current context we must be much more ambitious. We must achieve more effective guidelines that will really help to improve the development, effectiveness and simplicity of European legislation, for the sake of increased productivity, economic growth and job creation in the Union.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Decisions at European level affect more than 500 million of our population, so it is really crucial that we know the impacts and consequences of these decisions. The quality of the entire Impact Assessment process is therefore relevant for the whole development of our entire Union. I would like to highlight 3 following points. Firstly, I consider job creation to be the most important priority, which is why every proposal and every decision must be assessed according to this priority and, of course, the related impact on small businesses, because we know that the largest employers are small entrepreneurs. Secondly, the European Commission has set itself 10 priority areas, and we should be aware of the impacts of individual legal acts on these areas when making decisions, and it is important that these criteria do not go against each other and are counterproductive, but that, on the contrary, they are interrelated and interrelated. Last but not least, thirdly, I want to emphasise the irreplaceable role of the European Parliament as the only elected institution at European level, and I personally look forward to working with the European Commission precisely in the Impact Assessment process.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: Dear Commissioner, in this Chamber we often debate how to improve the conditions for doing business in Europe and to help enterprising and innovative companies create jobs and economic growth.  Access to finance is certainly one of the main problems facing small and medium-sized enterprises. In addition, we must put high on the agenda of the European institutions the issue of easing the administrative burden.   These issues are already a priority for the new Commission, where you will be and work for better regulation in the European Union. Congratulations on your strong speech behind the development of small and medium-sized enterprises earlier today in plenary. The principle of thinking first about small ones must continue to be applied through the systematic conduct of the so-called 'small and medium-sized enterprises test' in carrying out an impact assessment of future legislative initiatives. Given the environment of strong market competition in which most of them operate, even a small relief of administrative burden may prove decisive for the development and expansion of their activities.  It is incomprehensible and unacceptable to me that the Commission's revised draft guidelines do not include any provisions on the test for small and medium-sized enterprises. It must be integrated as a mandatory element in the impact assessment process and more attention should be paid to its appropriate implementation.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
