name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: Madam President, I will also try to respect my time to tell you that, listening to the information that the European Commission has just given us on the impact assessment, I think it is important to recall the initial point of this exercise. Indeed, impact analysis must remain a tool for European legislative and regulatory work. It is essential to provide objective and precise insight into the decisions taken by our institutions. Their decisions are never without constraints for all Member States and, therefore, consequences in the daily lives of European citizens.  However, we must remain very vigilant. These studies should not be an even more excessive source of regulation and an administration whose weight would impair the freedom to undertake and act. In this regard, I would therefore like to raise awareness among the European Commission about the lack of flexibility, not to say the blind rigidity of certain analyses. Let me close with a tip:Let's avoid one day having to do impact studies on the impact of impact studies.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Mr. President, we have heard that 85% of businesses belong to small and medium-sized enterprises, that this is very important and is the backbone of the economic agenda. Also, Mr. Timmermans, your ambitions are really encouraging and you are fully, as you said, committed to this cause and you need our support - I believe you will have it. However, I have one question, maybe you can answer me: creating this independent body that would guarantee the credibility of EU legislation, and we have already created you and your portfolio that actually talks about it - does that mean, that we are duplicating ourselves right inside the body? Is it necessary for someone to have to control the European Commission? If you are doing a fair performance assessment, if we remove all administrative burdens, if the laws are simple to us and if they are propulsive and we can simply implement them, why this independent body? I wish you could explain that in your closing argument.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, impact assessments are carried out to predict the likely consequence of EU legislation on citizens and the economy as a whole. However, they are often controversial and opaque.  I believe that a major challenge facing the new European Commission is to break down its impact assessment mechanisms from political imperatives that all too often guide the preparation of its proposals and instead rely on mere scientific evidence. There are countless examples in which European policy-makers have also bickered about scientific evidence on extremely technical issues.  I therefore believe that we need to develop a new system for collecting evidence within the Commission itself which completely disconnects the collection of evidence from the political imperative. Setting up a special department at the Commission with the role of evaluating policy proposals on the basis of mere scientific evidence would be important to ensure that the Commission's assessments are efficient, independent and transparent.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Commissioner, I would also point out that the evaluation of the impact of regulation is an area of great interest to me as a lawyer, and I think that, of course, millions of European citizens are rightly calling for quality European legislation. I was surprised that, if the Commission proposes an amendment to the existing legislation in force, the proposal is not accompanied by a translation of the text that is changing, it does not indicate precisely the comparison of the current and newly proposed text. In my opinion, this should also change for the clarity of the rule of law.  I would also advocate a specific assessment of the impact of the implementation of the principle of subsidiarity, especially after the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon and in the light of the work and opinions of the national parliaments.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, you could have come here to tell us how you want to make the European Commission's impact assessments more credible, more rigorous, more reasoned – assessments which, in most cases, are nothing more than a mere formality that never calls into question the interests of the lobbies that determine the European Commission's legislative proposals.  Instead, it chose to further discredit this instrument in the name of a supposed life-making for small and medium-sized enterprises. Want to make life easier for SMEs? For put an end to the impoverishment policies that crush the internal market on which SMEs, for the most part, depend, as happened in Portugal with the intervention of the troika. Put an end to the policies of favouritism of the major economic groups. Recognize that, contrary to what they proclaimed, the liberalisation and privatisation of strategic sectors of the economy subjected SMEs to the predation of monopolies and oligopolies, energy, telecommunications, banking, insurance and others... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: premier Vice-président de la Commission. - Madame la Présidente, tout d'abord, je voudrais exprimer ma reconnaissance envers les interprètes parce que les orateurs parlent tellement vite que je suis vraiment impressionné par leur travail. Secondly, let me take away any misunderstanding. The impact assessment on SMEs was, is and will remain part of the Commission’s impact assessment. The only thing I want to do is to improve that. I do not think it is good enough as it is. To explain the way it works: the services of the Commission who prepare legislation are themselves responsible for impact assessment. This impact assessment is then reviewed by the Impact Assessment Board, and until now approximately 40% of what was presented to the Board was sent back because it was not good enough and had to be reviewed. So I am fully conscious of the fact that the Commission services should do a better job at incorporating impact assessment when they draft legislation. What we are doing now is revising the guidelines so that we do a better job. Your contribution tonight is extremely valuable for me to make sure that I can put that into the debate to create better guidelines. The assumption that impact assessment would not be done for SMEs is not corroborated by the facts. Approximately 93% of the proposals have an entire or partial impact assessment for SMEs. I also believe that we could improve the Impact Assessment Board by making sure that we expand the membership of that Board with people who have experience in this field, who are clearly independent and who are willing to be very clear and brutal if they believe that the Commission is not doing a good job. My intention is to look very carefully at the composition of the Impact Assessment Board. Some of you have suggested that this Impact Assessment Board should be removed from the Commission. I am not of that opinion. I believe it should remain within the Commission, because what we do is assess drafts we make in the Commission before these drafts go to Parliament and the Council. So if you want impact assessment across the board for EU legislation, perhaps we could then have a talk with Parliament on how Parliament organises this and learn from each other and then also look at what the Council could still be doing. Impact assessment means looking at the impact on society in a broad sense. It is not just about whether it is legally well-drafted legislation. It also looks at the economic impact of this legislation. It looks at the social impact of this legislation. It looks at the environmental impact of this legislation. This is all of extreme importance for better regulation. Mr Telička suggested that perhaps we should also have financial targets. Well, let me say – and this is for better regulation, not for impact assessment, and I think it was also Mr Bütikofer who referred to that – that better regulation does not mean deregulation or less regulation. Better regulation can mean replacing 28 national regulations by one clear EU regulation, but it can also mean that the EU refrains from making regulations where perhaps the differences between the Member States are so big that if you make an EU regulation, it becomes so complicated that it is too much of a burden, especially on small and medium-sized enterprises. I want to take a completely rational approach to the issue. For me this is not an ideological issue, a party political issue; for me this is a rational issue. How do we attain the goals of sustainable growth in Europe without an undue burden on citizens and enterprises? That is the main goal of my operation in the next five years. I also believe that we need to review existing legislation. We have not been very good at that as a European Union in the last ten years. I think Mr Telička rightly pointed to that problem, and I really undertake to have a dialogue with this Parliament on how we can also remove outdated legislation or legislation that no longer attains the goals it was intended for. I agree with those of you who say ʽthink small firstʼ. Indeed, not just because there are so many SMEs in the EU, but also because helping SMEs is actually easier across the board than helping the big guys, because if you help SMEs remove just a part of the burden they have, you could create tremendous results in a very short period of time. But the SMEs have to be aware of this, and until now my impression is that whatever we have done at the European level, SMEs today do not have the feeling that we are taking the burden away from them. They have the feeling, as some of you rightly pointed out, that the only thing Europe does is add more burden to them, and we should be very aware of that feeling in European society, and we should be able to do something concretely about this jointly as the Commission/European Parliament. To sum up, Madam President: yes, SMEs will remain as part of impact assessment. Yes, we need to do better in impact assessment than we have done in the last couple of years. Yes, this is part of the better regulation exercise that will be complicated but necessary for growth in the European Union; and yes, the Commission is strongly committed to making sure that all stakeholders, and especially this Parliament, have a full say in how we develop this, and I hope that this can be reflected in the new guidelines the Commissions will be developing shortly.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, November 27, 2014.

name: Brian HAYES
text: Madam President, I want to deal briefly with the very significant problem of cigarette smuggling, which is a real issue across the European Union. I want to praise the recent action by the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) in an operation called Replica, which, in October this year, seized 130 million cigarettes on their way to my country and other countries. What I am looking for this evening is a commitment to much greater cooperation and integration between OLAF, the Europe-wide anti-smuggling agency, the national coastguards and also the customs and revenue services in the various Member States. We need our role here to be more integrated to make sure that we do much more to stop the smuggling of cigarettes.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as a result of the ECB's stress tests on one hundred and thirty-one European banks, twenty-five have not passed them, falling below the minimum capital requirements. Given that one hundred and twenty-five billion new jobs can be disbursed with ten billion capital, one wonders how the banking system will ensure the necessary flow of capital to the production system. I reject the idea of having to look for the answer at the finance table, where Perhaps Italy does not sit with equal weight compared to other countries. text: At the end of each plenary session, the European Parliament deals with violations of fundamental human rights in third countries. name: Siôn SIMON
text: Madam President, the last time I was here I spoke about the European Youth Initiative, the Youth Guarantee and the failure of the UK Government in the second year of the scheme to draw down any of these funds. name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Madam President, a democratic exercise was held in Catalonia on 9 November in which more than two million people reflected their opinion at the ballot box. The Spanish state's response was again denial and judicial threats, an anti-democratic reaction that contrasts powerfully with others we have seen recently within the European Union itself. The same is true in my country, Euskal Herria: imposition and denial of the right to decide. The Spanish state has pending a profound modification of its foundations, it has a pending break with this undemocratic slope. I encourage the European Parliament to continue working so that the right of self-determination of peoples, their recognition, is exactly what it is: a democratic principle which does not depend on the size of a Member State and which is, at last, a European principle.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: Madam President, in the sense that Jon Juaristi spoke, two million three hundred thousand people took to the streets on 9 November for a day of citizen and political participation on his future. One million eight hundred thousand people voted for independence from Catalonia. The Spanish Government had banned this citizen participation and has prompted the courts to convict the President of Catalonia and two members of his Government. It is incomprehensible that a State of the European Union wants to prevent citizens from voting freely on its future. It seems to me that the time is coming for the European Democrats and the European Parliament to openly defend the democratic rights of Catalans.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to draw attention to the fact that in Greece the state operator of the electricity transmission system, ADMIE, is being privatised. A year ago, both the Chinese State Grid Corporation and the Italian operator Terna expressed interest in the purchase of their Greek counterpart. However, the State Grid Corporation of China itself, through the control of State Grid International Development Limited, is now terna's indirect partner in Italy. So we are in a paradoxical situation, where Terna and State Grid Corporation are allied in Italy and at the same time competitors in Greece for the purchase of ADMIE. This is the consequence of the need for Member States to cash in by selling off their national and therefore European strategic assets in order to respond to austerity policies, which has already happened in Italy and which is happening throughout southern Europe. I call on everyone to keep an eye on the way in which the European Commission will try to sew a patch on this paradox and on so many others that I cannot expose here for time.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: On the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, we can see that many promises in the countries on the eastern side of the Iron Curtain remained unfulfilled and that the path of decommissioning of totalitarian systems has not yet ended in Slovenia. This year in Slovenia we also remember the 25th anniversary of the founding of Demos, which was a central player in the formation of a general national consensus on independence and democratisation of Slovenia.  In Slovenia, despite our membership of the European Union and NATO, we are still facing a failed transition, which is most manifested in the state of Slovenian justice, which represents the main obstacle to the creation of a free, fair and democratic society. The European Commission has already stressed that the state of the Slovenian justice system is unsatisfactory.  The Slovenian government has not carried out the lustation and the tops of the judiciary are occupied by people who have grossly violated human rights under the previous regime. For all of the above, it seems that in Slovenia the Berlin Wall still stands.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Madam President, I want to make you aware tonight of several facts that are happening in our immediate neighbourhood and not only should Croatia be concerned about Serbia's behaviour towards Russia. There is a veiled outing among many diplomats over Putin's visit to Belgrade, a military parade in his honour, but also military exercises by Serbia-Russia special forces near the Croatian border, which is no longer just Croatia but also the external border of NATO and the European Union. Therefore, provocation could also be discussed. We were not impressed by the latest developments in the release of indicted Seselj by the International Court of Justice in The Hague, but neither was Minister Dacic's laconic statement that Serbia must achieve a sea exit.  If relations between Russia and the Western world deteriorate, Serbia will have to step out of its neutral stance and will have to choose a side as a candidate for accession, but the Union will no longer be allowed to remain silent if we really want southeast European countries to join the Union.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at this difficult time, at a time when community and religious tensions are flourishing, we need secularism more than necessary. In this context, Pope Francis' speech in plenary is regrettable.  The European Parliament Chamber is not the place for a religious discourse. How can we fight for freedom and fundamental rights, how can we combat discrimination if professional organisations can interfere with democratic choices?  The European Union protects freedom of opinion and belief. Why is it not protected from the influence of religions? Finally, let us adopt a European definition of secularism, just and necessary, it is it that allows us to live together despite our differences. And I will end with these words of Gambetta: "We are not the enemies of religion. We are, on the contrary, the servants of freedom of conscience, respectful of all religious and philosophical opinions."

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Let me make a comment on the functioning of the internal market. On 8 August, the European Commission published a letter addressed to several international car rental companies. In it, it called for an end to discriminatory practices against European consumers who cannot rent an online car at the lowest price available, depending on their nationality or place of residence.  On 28 October, the Commission informed the Commission of the agreement reached with representatives of car rental companies, but they would nevertheless be able to charge different prices on the basis of objective criteria, according to the Commission communication. I believe that distinguishing the price indicated on the website according to the language version or place of residence of the consumer is always a discriminatory pricing practice. The objective criteria referred to by the Commission are not justified in this case and, in my view, are infringements of the Services Directive. I therefore call on the European Commission and Commissioner Bieńkowska to focus on these practices.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, sixty-nine years have passed since the end of the Second World War and yet Germany refuses to pay Greece the war reparations awarded to it by the Paris International Conference in 1946 amounting to EUR 108 billion. The amount of the loan was EUR 1 million, excluding interest. It also refuses to sign a Peace Treaty with Greece even though both countries are members of the European Union. At the same time, Germany refuses to return home the compulsory occupation loan imposed in 1942 on occupied Greece, which currently amounts to EUR 54 billion, without interest. Because of this loan the Greek economy was dissolved and more than 600°000 Greeks died of hunger. Also 56°000 Greek patriots were executed by Nazi occupation troops and 105°000 were murdered in German concentration camps. All this is contained in the Black Paper published by Mr Manolis Glezos. EUR 162 billion Without interest, Germany must pay... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Madam Chairman, one of the strategic objectives of the European Union is quality infrastructure connectivity of member states. In this context, road connections and rail connectivity are of utmost importance. That is why here I call on the Commission to complete the connection of the road from Koper to Buje, from Postojna to Rupa and Rijeka and from Maribor towards the border with Croatia together with the Republic of Slovenia and the Republic of Croatia. Namely, these road connections are of utmost importance for the competitiveness of the Port of Rijeka, for Istrian tourism and, of course, for the communication of citizens between Zagreb and Maribor. In this context, it is also my request that the European Commission take significant account of the possibility of financing these projects.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: Madam President, democracy in Greece is being violated without a doubt when its citizens living abroad cannot vote in national elections and especially when, as a result of the crisis, there is a wave of mainly young people. The Greek state prevents all of them from exercising their democratic rights, as the cost of travel is prohibitive. Will only the rich vote after all? Why is the Greek government deaf to the appeals of Greek communities and not allowing expatriate Greeks to vote from their countries of residence when they vote in the European elections instead? Why does the Greek Government not respect the relevant resolutions of the European Parliament and do not apply an earlier relevant law? Why isn't the European Union pressuring the Greek government when it's cutting back on bailing out the banks? So who's afraid of who in this crisis?

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Madam President, on the 22nd of this month there was an event of enormous gravity in the waters of the Canary Islands. Boats of the environmental organization Greenpeace, which protested peacefully against the start of Repsol's oil explorations, were attacked by boats of the Spanish Navy. This is a serious fact, ladies and gentlemen, since the right to peaceful protest and freedom of expression enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union has been infringed. The use of the army for public security tasks has also caused alarm in much of the population. The violence of the performance also left one of the activists injured by the impact of a propeller from one of the vessels. We want to bring these serious facts to the known to this House and call for the release of the Vessel Arctic Sunrise, which is still being retained. And we strongly defend the right of civil society to protest against the ecological crimes of its rulers. Release Arctic Sunrise and stop prospecting.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the cap-and-trade system was introduced in the Doha Round as an instrument that should have made it possible to reduce climate gas emissions, as decided by the Kyoto Protocol, in the most efficient and economical way. It was thought that entrusting the definition of the cost of emissions to the market could encourage more virtuous behaviour and penalise companies that did not want to invest in the best technologies. From the end of the first trading period, when a tonne of CO2 cost a few cents, the instrument put in place showed its profound limitations. The whole climate and energy package voted on at the beginning of 2009 is based on co2 cost forecasts that are very far removed from reality. In order to combat the climate change that is taking place, we need serious instruments that leave no room for the parasitism of brokers and financial markets, the only ones for which the ETS is working very well. The time has therefore come to start a serious discussion and discussion with all the parties to understand how to overcome the cap and trade system so that we can make full and effective use of the resources available.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Madam President, in recent years in Europe, a large part of our fellow citizens have been living below the poverty line because of austerity policies and fiscal adjustment measures implemented in many Member States of the European Union to deal with the economic crisis. According to Eurostat data for 2013, one hundred and twenty million Europeans live under this regime. My country Greece ranks third among the countries of Europe with the highest poverty rates, while unemployment exceeds 27%. This reveals the depth of the crisis. Some four million Greeks are destitute and socially excluded who are unable to make a living necessary because, among other things, some 230°000 small and medium-sized enterprises have closed, many jobs have been lost and the phenomena of social impoverishment have increased dramatically. Europe must now effectively tackle the spread of poverty and must pursue a long-term strategy aimed at gradually restoring the standard of living of Europeans, especially in countries where the phenomenon is particularly pronounced.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Mr President, I would like to raise the alarm about the strong, fact-based suspicions about the existence of the political process and the endangerment of press freedom in my country. After the revelations made to the television station belonging to the Voiculescu family, proven with recordings, in which the brother of the President of Romania took the sum of 250,000 euros to escape the conviction of a known interloper, the trial of the founder of the press trust, who has been before the courts for six years, was reinstated and tried in five days. Unreasonable deadlines, of only one day, during the judicial holiday, the non-admission of the 124 exceptions raised by lawyers, the non-admission of neutral expertise, as requested by the Constitutional Court, led to the conviction of 12 people, and the politician Dan Voiculescu, founder of the press trust that reported the news, received the maximum penalty. Finally, the extensive confiscation was carried out on third parties who were not part of the trial and could not defend themselves, thus taking measures of economic strangulation on the post which made the disclosure. So here's how freedom of the press is threatened and citizens' rights to defence are violated.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Madam President, I do not think it needs to be particularly stressed in this House that the financial situation in Ukraine, the economic situation in Ukraine, is rather shaky. Although we were very pleased to accept the Association Agreement with Ukraine recently, I believe that this also involves responsibility, because the European Union has entered into an association relationship with a very large country and indeed the problems are great. The approaching winter, on the other hand, suggests very serious energy supply problems in Ukraine, and I miss whether the European institutions have, have built, an adequate energy security strategy, which serves the energy security not only of the European Member States, but also of the associated Member State, Ukraine. Now it is better to speak than to fight the humanitarian catastrophe later.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Madam President, we are going to celebrate International Day Against Machist Violence tomorrow and there is still much left to eradicate this machismo from society. 52% of the European population is women and, with the figures provided by the study carried out by the European Union's Agency for Fundamental Rights, sixty-two million women in Europe have experienced sexist violence. When, we ask women, will these policies be taken seriously and no longer be part of only politically correct discourse? In the Agency's own words, it is an abuse of human rights that the European Union cannot and cannot ignore, nor can it look the other way. That is why we are calling on the Union to ratify the Istanbul Convention, to increase resources for prevention programmes and not to make cuts in victim protection, as has happened in Spain, where it has been cut by 35%. So let's work together and eradicate this scourge at once.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: Madam President, next Wednesday the European Commission will present in this Parliament the investment programme, a sine qua non condition of Mr Juncker's inauguration in July. In recent days many have been the information or rumors about the source of resources to finance that 300 billion euros. However, we have hardly heard anything about how investment projects will be selected and what the criteria for distributing funding will be among the different projects to be financed.  However, in Spain, an alleged report has already been leaked in which the Government of the nation – the Government of Spain – prioritizes a series of investment projects without the competition of the autonomous communities and without public information, an example of the disloyalties of the Spanish Government. In this regard, I request from here the European Commission and Mr Timmermans to guarantee independence in the selection of investment projects and to require Member States to have a transparent selection process, with the participation of the autonomous communities and my constituency, Asturias, among them.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: In Romania, the Ceausescu dictatorship failed 25 years ago. The most beautiful gift of this year's jubilee is the election of Klaus Johannis, a democratic-liberal Saxon politician from Transylvania, as President of the State. Over the past quarter of a century, the former Communists have returned to power several times. Socialist presidential candidate Victor Ponta's election defeat dealt a decisive blow to nationalist restoration and paved the way for the continuation of democratic transitions. During the election, the so-called Obama effect prevailed. As in Timisoara 25 years ago, the multi-ethnic and multi-religion Transylvania played a decisive role in the regime change. The Hungarians and Germans persecuted by Ceausescu, together with the majority of their Romanian compatriots, all voted for Klaus Johannis. Hope is back in Romania!

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Madam President, last Friday the whole of Latvia commemorated the anniversary of the tragedy in Riga’s Zolitŭde district. One year ago, the roof of the Maxima supermarket collapsed upon shoppersʼ heads. Fifty-four people perished, including three rescuers. In this tragedy, 23 children lost one parent, and one child lost both father and mother. It was the gravest accident in the whole history of Latvia as an independent state and the biggest catastrophe in Eastern Europe for the past 30 years. These people died not because of an act of terrorism, war or natural disaster, but in a time of peace, and in a shop. One year has passed, but the Latvian Government authorities have still not brought anybody to justice. Society ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: I want to ask a question about the performance of daylight saving time. After we started moving the clock in Europe a few decades ago in relation to winter and daylight saving time, the main purpose of this measure was primarily to save energy. To date, progress has brought different lifestyles, adjustments in the economy, agriculture, industry, transport and these are no longer so dependent on summer time. Energy savings have also been found to be spent in the morning, which is why many countries in Asia, Africa and South America have stopped this transition to daylight saving time. Our citizens are, for the most part, critical of this issue, because it is about breaking down the sleeping routine and it is difficult to adapt to the impact on well-being. I therefore appeal to the Commission to conduct this in-depth debate and to establish the performance of this measure.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Madam President, the alarming figures on youth unemployment force us to ask ourselves whether or not we can have a secure future for our young people. As a young MEP, I understand very well the problems that young people face: a lack of confidence in society, in institutions, but also in their own development capacities.  Young people need us, the European Parliament, the European Commission and the rest of the institutions to develop, dare and take their lives into their own hands. There are 5.3 million young people without an occupation in Europe, for which we owe it to us to act.  As an S&D member, I say that we need to increase the amount of the Youth Guarantee, invest more, more determinedly and intelligently. Every euro cent we now invest in the potential of our young people means an invaluable investment in the future. We must open Europe to large investments, transnational projects, which will bring the necessary resources for programmes dedicated to young people. That is why I say that young people should be encouraged to pursue their destiny in Europe, gain experience and be an active part of European society.
